PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 2.15 p.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Funding of Children's Services
To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That funding in the area of children's services, which has been reduced by almost 40 per cent in real terms over the last five years, should be restored forthwith to at least the real value of funding allocated in the 1975-76 Budget. And further, that annual Budget allocations in the area of children's services should be spent in full for the purposes designated.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child,Mr Free and Mr Mountford.

PETITION.TITLE: National Health Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in view of the recent standardisation of insulin and insulin syringes, having the effect of increasing the cost of both items to the Diabetic in general, and as every insulin-dependent Diabetic must use the same, daily or twice daily according to medication.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that syringes be made available on the NHS and that insulin prescriptions revert to 10 bottles as previously supplied.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cunningham,Mr Duffy and Mr Mountford.

PETITION.TITLE: Air Fares to Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That air fares to Tasmania should not be increased.
2. That air fares to Tasmania are vital to the growing Tourist Industry.
3. That air travel is the only way, apart from one ANL ship, that commuting is possible between the mainland of Australia and the island of Tasmania.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that air fares to Tasmania should not be increased.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-
That the plan to obliterate the traditional weights and measures of this country is causing and will cause widespread inconvenience, confusion, expense and distress.
That there is no certainty that any significant benefits or indeed any benefits at all will follow the use of the new weights and measures.
That the traditional weights and measures are eminently satisfactory.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the Metric Conversion Act be repealed, and that the Government take urgent steps to cause the traditional and familiar units to be restored to those areas where the greatest inconvenience and distress are occurring, that is to say, in meteorology, in road distances, in sport, in the building and allied trades, in the printing trade, and in retail trade.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Service Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-

(1) That merchant seamen have in the past served in theatres of war; they have been decorated for valor following war action; they have been prisoners of war and should therefore be entitled to similar pensioner rights and medical benefits as regular servicemen.
(2) That by being denied the entitlements, such as pension and medical benefits, which other war veterans receive, they are thereby being discriminated against.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government amend the Repatriation Act (1920) Section 100 (d) (iv) to take account of war-related service by merchant seamen during World War 2.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Labelling of Cosmetics
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.

That the Industries Assistance Commission, because of the Commission's terms of reference, seems unable to impose any regulation or recommend any regulation which might restrict the activities of Cosmetic Companies which produce cosmetics in which animal ingredients have been used, or for which animals were subjected to research.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will:
Legislate to require comprehensive labelling of perfumes, cosmetics and toilet preparations to indicate:
(1) whether a product contains any animal derivative. If so, the ingredient and source should be indicated.
(2) whether the research and development of that product or any of its ingredients involved experimentation on animals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology or environment.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the interim list of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, take into consideration the protection of the island.
3. That the Queensland Government has recently renewed a further mining lease against the advice of conservationists.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to refuse requests for export permits covering mineral sand products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Norwood North Post Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-
That hardship and inconvenience would be caused to the community by the proposed closure on 31st March 1981 of the Norwood North Post Office (non-official) 142 Magill Road, Norwood, SA.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Minister of Communications will intercede on behalf of Norwood and Stepney residents and have abandoned the proposal to close the Norwood North Post Office.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Exports of Live Animals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Government promotes carcass trade and that all future shipments of live animals overseas for slaughter be banned, and thereby stop a repetition of the shocking loss of life through burns or drowning as occurred with the incineration or drowning of 40,000 sheep on a ship to abattoirs in the Middle East, or the more recent cruelty to horses being exported for slaughter in Japan.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposal to sell Trans-Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans Australia Airlines within 5 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans Australia Airlines would inevitably result in-
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans Australia Airlines.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Breeders' Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are gravely concerned at the prospect of any legislation regarding Plant Variety Rights.
The reasons are as follows:
1. We believe it would transfer control, the key aspect of agriculture in this country, to overseas interests not responsible to the Australian Government.
2. We believe it would restrict the growing and trading of many seeds.
3. We believe it would cause a decline in the genetic diversity of crops making them more subject to destruction by pests and diseases.
4. We believe thorough investigation of the effect of similar legislation overseas and a full public debate is required before any decision is made.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament refrains from enacting any legislation on Plant Variety Rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Debendox
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(a) that the Minister for Health should remove the morning sickness drug Debendox from sale immediately and,
(b) Commonwealth laboratories should be set up to test and evaluate those drugs imported into Australia and that these laboratories be financed by the drug companies.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the morning sickness drug Debendox be immediately removed from sale and Commonwealth laboratories be set up to test and evaluate drugs imported into Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Isaacs respectfully showeth:

That the Family Law Act should be amended to limit child support orders to a set scale, to provide custody of children to the parent not primarily responsible for the breakdown of the marriage and establish a set schedule for division of matrimonial property that cannot be varied at the discretion of any judge.
These measures would reduce the divorce rate and re-establish stability and security in family life.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Family Law Act be amended to abolish the maintenance and alimony system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Macquarie respectfully showeth:
That we consider the lack of service provided by Telecom Australia in Sydney's 047 telephone zone is not only inconvenient but is affecting families, business concerns and employment in the area.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government direct Telecom Australia to provide an adequate service to subscribers and users in the 047 telephone zone.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefit Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned Pharmaceutical Chemists of South Australia sheweth:
That the Professional Fee paid by the Commonwealth of Australia for the dispensing of Pharmaceutical Benefit Prescriptions has not been increased since the 1st July, 1977.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
In respect to the provision of Pharmaceutical Benefits by approved chemists throughout Australia, take such action as will ensure that the Government will immediately act to:
(1) increase the remuneration paid to pharmacists for dispensing Pharmaceutical Benefit Prescriptions.
(2) restore the level of pharmacists' Professional Fees to at least the equivalent of that applicable in 1977-78, adjusted by the previously agreed formula for up-dating pharmacists' remuneration.

(3) acknowledge all other increases in costs which are not reflected in the up-dating formula but which have severely disadvantaged pharmacists financially to the extent that the majority of pharmacists are not recovering the costs incurred in dispensing Pharmaceutical Benefits.

(4) insist that the valuable contribution made to the community by pharmacists in health care delivery outside of the immediate Pharmaceutical Benefit supply function be recognised when the levels of remuneration are determined.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Airline Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:
That we protest most strongly against the present two airline domestic policy of the Commonwealth Government.
That this policy has resulted in expensive airfares and poor service and discourages tourists from the Eastern States visiting WA and vice versa.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will look favourably on our petition and formulate an Airline Policy providing for greater competition so that prices and service are determined by free market forces.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister for Health by noting that the excuse for the Government's near total inactivity in the health field during 1980 was that it was waiting on the Jamison report. As the Government has now had the Jamison report for three months, is it possible yet for the Minister to tell the House when the Government will make any specific response to any of the major recommendations of that report?
—No, it is not.

—I ask the Minister for Administrative Services: Is it a fact that over recent months officers of the Australian Federal Police Force have entered the surgeries of a number of medical practitioners and have taken possession of patients' files? If so, can the Minister say how many times this has occurred in the past 12 months? Is it correct that in some instances original patients' files have been retained by the Federal Police for many months without any charges being laid? What official procedure has been adopted by the Federal Police Force to protect the private and confidential nature of patients' files? Finally, is the Minister satisfied that that procedure gives proper protection to the traditional relationship between patient and doctor?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member asked a very important question. It relates to a matter which I know has concerned many honourable members. Perhaps I should respond to the last part of the question first; that is, that part relating to the relationship between the doctor and the patient. I think that really should be answered by my colleague, the Minister for Health. In cases which involve possible fraud, et cetera, against the National Health Act the procedure is this: Usually, the Department of Health conducts an investigation and at a certain stage in the investigation it calls in the police. The role of the police thereafter is to investigate any possible breach of the law.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that under the law the police in their investigation have the power to seize documents. They can do that when a search warrant has been issued under the Commonwealth Crimes Act. Once the documents have been seized the police are very conscious of the need to maintain the confidentiality and security of those documents. I am advised that to that end last year the Commissioner of Police issued guidelines which set down the way in which those documents are to be kept confidential. I add that I am advised that the Australian Medical Association has sighted those guidelines and has expressed satisfaction with them.

I think the honourable member would be interested to know also that the Attorney-General has made a reference to the Australian Law Reform Commission on the matter of privacy. It is expected that the Law Reform Commission in that context will look at the whole matter of the seizure of medical documents. It is also interesting to note some comments made by Mr Justice Kirby when he was addressing members of the General Practitioners Society in Australia, which he is reported to have done on 23 March. In that speech he said that the Law Reform Commission was considering a uniform regime which would normally require judicial authorisation before powers of entry, search and seizure could be exercised by Federal officials. Mr Justice Kirby is reported to have said this also, which is very pertinent to the whole problem:

It would appear to me to be too facile to say that a doctor's records should not be examined without his consent, or even his patient's consent, when investigating an offence alleged against the doctor or patient himself . . . Otherwise we could be committing investigations and enforcement of the criminal law and breaches of statute to the consent of the very person under suspicion or other persons upon whom he may sometimes exercise influence.

I think another example of the enormity of the problem is a case reported on 24 March which relates to a doctor who has been charged and in which it has been alleged to the court that $200,000 may be involved in possible crimes against Medibank. All I would add is that I remind honourable members that, if there are problems with, and complaints against, the police, under the Commonwealth Ombudsman Act 1976 people may refer those complaints to the Commonwealth Ombudsman. That ability is enhanced by the powers which will be conferred under the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Bill which has just been before this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Health been drawn to the main front page story in the Melbourne Herald of 23 March? Is it a fact that the fifth Fraser health scheme will provide identity cards for the poor, regressive insurance for the rich and Hobson's choice for the remainder?

—In fact I did read the Melbourne Herald of that date. I am not going to add to any speculation as to what may be the Government's response to matters contained in the report of the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals. Suffice it to say that the report is a most important one. It covers a tremendous range of subjects of enormous significance to all Australians. The Commonwealth Government is giving it the proper consideration it should.

—Is the Minister for Health aware of recent Press reports concerning the plight of hospitals in Tasmania in relation to cost cutting measures imposed by the Tasmanian Government? Is it correct that these measures have been forced on the Tasmanian Government because of the Federal Government's failure to honour the fifty-fifty cost sharing arrangements? Will the Minister please advise this House of the true situation in relation to the funding of hospitals in Tasmania and once and for all stop the Tasmanian Government battering this Federal Government over the head?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that some State governments, particularly those of the Labor States-New South Wales and Tasmania -seem to be endeavouring to whip up a climate of hysteria in relation to the funding of hospitals. It is not true in any way, shape, sense or form that the Commonwealth has at any time failed to live up to its promises in relation to the fifty-fifty cost sharing of the net operating costs of each State's public hospitals. In fact this year there is an increase in the total amount made available of about $144m, or overall about 12.3 per cent. It was made perfectly clear to the States that the Commonwealth would maintain the amount of money available at the 1979 levels. Any increases in services above those operating in 1979 would have to be offset by reductions in other parts of the agreed cost sharing formula.

ANSWER.PARA: So the States have the opportunity to organise their hospital systems as they wish. Of course there is the capacity to escalate some of the factors. I gave an undertaking to all the Ministers for Health at the recent Health Ministers conference in Western Australia that if they had particular matters they wished to bring before the Commonwealth we would be prepared to look at them. But the fact of the matter is that the funding for hospitals has not been reduced. In fact it has been maintained at the real levels operating in 1979. I repeat that overall there has been a 12.3 per cent increase this year, or about $144m. That increase applies throughout Australia, including Tasmania. Some of the instances of the administration of the hospitals in Tasmania that the Tasmanian Minister for Health brought before the Ministers conference in Western Australia would make me, if I were that State Minister, look very closely at the administration of that State's hospitals. It is up to the States to administer the hospitals, not to bleat to the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware of requests made by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission that there be set up working parties representing metal trades employer organisations and metal union organisations to look at the introduction of shorter working hours in the metal industries? Has he directly used his office to persuade metal employers not to co-operate with the working parties, in defiance of the Arbitration Commission's requests?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand this proposal, it was basically a union proposal. The metal trades employers, initially indicated that they would examine it but they said that they wanted to assess the views of their membership around Australia. As I am advised, the view of the membership was that they should not participate in an arrangement which was designed to achieve a reduction in working hours and which was plainly seen to be designed to achieve a reduction in working hours. I find it very difficult to understand how leaders in the union movement and also in the Australian Labor Party so avidly support a 35-hour, working week and arrangements in relation to a 35-hour working week when they know quite well that will increase costs of manufacturing in Australia by 14 per cent to 20 per cent or more and when they know quite well that that will lead to the sale of less Australian made goods and therefore to the employment of fewer Australians. I would have thought that at the moment we would have wanted a circumstance where as many Australians as possible could be employed. To achieve that we need to sell as many Australian goods as possible. Why leaders of the union movement should show such a blatant and callous disregard for the employment of people who do not have jobs I fail utterly to understand.

ANSWER.PARA: We have only to look at the tactics in which certain trade unions indulged in relation to the Altona case. There were circumstances there of industrial blackmail and guerrilla tactics which would have been designed to put companies out of business totally. As a result of that kind of pressure and industrial force, some kind of agreement was put to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the Commission was asked to endorse it. The whole process is a shabby one indeed. The whole process is one that can result only in higher unemployment than would otherwise be the case. The architect of higher unemployment in this Parliament, the honourable member for Wills and former President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, needs to be branded as the architect of wage policies and industrial policies which have done a great deal of damage to the Australian community. One of the odd things about it is that he has the intelligence to understand it and to know it very plainly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware of the urgency of establishing an overall management system for the long term control of salinity in the River Murray and all its tributaries as well as the regulation of the quantity of water available for domestic, industrial and irrigation usage? Will he consider formulating a specific national policy in this regard to guide the various authorities involved? Will he give thought to establishing an investigating body to determine exactly the technical matters which must govern the development of the Murray and its tributaries in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The importance of the River Murray and its tributaries to three States is enormous. In more recent times we have heard, and we hear now, many people refer to Australia's great natural resources. By that they generally mean minerals or reserves of coal. The River Murray and its tributaries may well be Australia's greatest continuing natural resource. I use the word 'continuing' advisedly because it will be a continuing natural resource only if the three State governments concerned and the Commonwealth jointly undertake the appropriate management arrangements and pursue the appropriate policies which will protect the Murray for all the purposes and activities that are associated with it.

ANSWER.PARA: Over a long period the Commonwealth has provided substantial funds to help the States combat salinity, and that process continues. At the moment Senator Carrick is negotiating with the States to achieve a new agreement, and as I understand it there is good progress in that direction. It is our hope that that agreement will be finalised quite shortly. The urgency is, of course, understood. This is not something that can be put off for five years or 10 years. With continuing dry times in New South Wales and in the south-eastern part of Australia it can become a very urgent problem very quickly. I believe the first step is to get that agreement with all the States. I think then we need to assess the priorities of the Commonwealth and the States in respect of the River Murray Agreement. I believe there would be complete agreement with the objectives that the honourable member would have in mind.

I know that the question was not asked purely from a South Australian point of view. Obviously, because South Australia is at the end of the River Murray, what happens in New South Wales and in Victoria is of vast importance to South Australia, so much of whose development depends on good quality water getting down the Murray. I know that the honourable gentleman's question was couched in terms of the River Murray as a whole. The concern that is presently felt in South Australia is something of which I and the Government are very conscious.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Prime Minister by reminding him that this day, for the first time since August of last year, national figures on registered unemployed have been issued. They total just under half a million, at 482,366. That is an increase of just under 20,000 on the figures for February of last year, or an increase of 4.2 per cent over the last year. They are the highest February figures since the war. Does the Prime Minister seriously suggest that the member for Wills is the architect of these figures, or does he regard these figures as further evidence of the tragic inefficacy of his Government's economic policies in general and final proof of his failure to fulfil the promise made more than five years ago to establish full employment in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures produced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics are generally regarded as being of greater validity. The honourable gentleman may not want to accept that, but that happens to be the case. Over the last 12 months, indeed over the last two years, employment in Australia has been growing very strongly. Total employment has grown in this country much more strongly than in nearly any other Western country. The Australian performance is all the more remarkable because in earlier times the Australian economy would grow if world trade was growing, if there was a buoyant situation overseas. But if there were difficulty and recession in Britain, the United States or the major countries of Europe, very severe recession would be felt in Australia. As a result of our policies over the last five years, this country has gone against the world trend. While the economies of other countries have been shrinking the Australian economy has been expanding, and Australian employment has been expanding. It will continue to expand and to grow under the policies of this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable gentleman knows quite well that the policies that he devised when he was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, that led to wage increases of nearly 40 per cent in one year, in 1975, were directly responsible for the massive growth of unemployment in this country. He will know also that as President of the ACTU, when he was very much concerned in devising and forming the 35-hour working week campaign, to gain support from certain areas--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. I claim to have been misrepresented.
—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. I must inform the honourable gentleman that I will call him for the making of a personal explanation at the appropriate time.

—Mr Speaker, if the honourable gentleman wishes to claim that he was not responsible in 1974 and 1975 for the wages policies that the union movement was then pursuing, with the active connivance and support of the government of the day, he will only be pleading his own impotence. If that is the way he wants to do it, he will be judged accordingly.

—Is the Minister for Communications aware that since Monday 16 March the North Sydney Post Office has been the subject of persistent industrial disruption, causing great hardship and inconvenience to those who live and work in the North Sydney area? Is he also aware that the North Sydney Post Office has a deplorable record for industrial disruption and that it services, when it is operating, the fifth largest commercial centre in Australia? Can the Minister tell this House what steps are being taken for the urgent settlement of the present industrial disruption to North Sydney's postal services?

—There has been some difficulty in respect of mail sorting and delivery staff at North Sydney Post Office. As I understand the position there have been some accommodation difficulties which are now under review by Australia Post. The difficulties have arisen in particular because of the presence of several agitators, all of whom have held or hold office as union delegates. One of those union delegates has been dismissed and the other one has been transferred to another office. I understand that the period within which appeals may be lodged against this disciplinary action expires at the end of this week. In the meantime there has been a series of rolling strikes which have seriously disrupted mail supplies in North Sydney. I am advised that successively different sectors of the staff have either failed to turn up for work or have failed to perform work when they have arrived. As a result, there have been very significant disruptions to mail deliveries in the electorate of the honourable gentleman. I am told that there is a large private box installation at North Sydney Post Office. Except for 80 bags, mail for box addresses that has come to the office has been sorted into the boxes. I am told that pension cheques have been delivered and a deal of other mail addressed to street addresses has also been delivered. However, there is two days mail in the office awaiting street delivery and about 900 bags for North Sydney are being held in other Sydney sorting offices because there is no space currently available at North Sydney. Existing staff would take about 10 days to clear all of the arrears. However, mail posted at North Sydney is being cleared. The present circumstances are of considerable concern to Australia Post. I am told that the disciplinary action currently being taken is expected to resolve the dispute, and I hope, very shortly.

—My question, which is directed to the Treasurer, relates to the sale by the Bell group of companies yesterday of $53m worth of shares in Elder Smith Goldsborough Mort Ltd, the shares having been acquired mostly in the previous few days. Is the Treasurer aware that the shares were sold for a profit of $16.5m but that section 26AAA tax on such share trading profit is unlikely to apply as the Bell group acquired its shares through an interposed subsidiary company and sold the shares by selling that subsidiary company rather than directly selling the shares as such? Is the Treasurer concerned that by this device tax revenue of some $7.5m will be avoided? If that is so, what, if anything, does he intend to do about it?

—I am aware of newspaper reports to the effect that the Bell group of companies has earned a very large profit on the sale of shares in Elder Smith Goldsborough Mort Ltd. I welcome very much, in the context of a degree of national economic rationality, the decision of the South Australian Government not to intervene in the marketplace decision. That stands in contrast with the activities of some other governments in a similar context. In direct response to the question of the honourable member for Chifley I say that, notwithstanding the newspaper reports, I am not at present in full possession of the facts surrounding the matter. The honourable gentleman is as aware as I am of certain provisions of the income tax legislation that prevent any Minister, including the Treasurer, from obtaining details that would not otherwise be publicly available about the affairs of a taxpayer, and that extends to this taxpayer and this group of companies.
—What about this particular device?

—The honourable gentleman should not get excited. It applies also to any other taxpayer in the Australian community. The honourable member for Chifley knows very well that I would be concerned if this transaction revealed any undue or improper weakness in the taxation law. To the extent that it is possible for me, consistent with the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act, to gather further information about it I will do so. If there is any need-I stress 'if'-for a change to be made I will certainly consider it and make a recommendation to the Government. I say that against the background of the fact that this group of companies and other people are engaged in market transactions. People invested money in purchasing shares. It is no part of the philosophy of this Government to get in the way of people trading freely and, if necessary, vigorously on stock exchanges throughout this country.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health. In view of the increased danger to Australia of diseases such as foot and mouth disease and the speed with which these animal diseases can be transmitted because of air travel, I ask: What was the time lag between the realisation by the New Zealand authorities that the recent animal disease outbreak near Timaru could be foot and mouth disease and their notification of this to the Department of Health? Did the Minister's Department first receive notice from the New Zealand officials, the world reference centre or the media? What was the time lag between his Department receiving this advice and contacting officials at Australian airports? Did a plane from Christchurch land at an Australian airport and did its passengers proceed through Customs during that period? Finally, can these time lags be reduced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman has raised a most important matter. Obviously the question of quarantine is of the utmost significance to a country such as Australia. When this incident occurred, anticipating that I might be asked a question of this nature, I took the trouble to find out in detail what the situation was. The outbreak was diagnosed on a property near Timaru on 11 February. The property was declared an infected place at about 4.30 New Zealand time on that day. The New Zealand Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries issued the first Press release of a suspected outbreak at 9.30 a.m. New Zealand time. Unofficial reports in Australia of this suspected outbreak were confirmed with New Zealand authorities by officers of my Department in a telephone discussion which took place at approximately 11.15 a.m. on the 12th. This further confirmatory advice on the suspected outbreak was contained in a cable received by my Department from New Zealand authorities at 1.43 p.m. Australian time.

ANSWER.PARA: The first reports that we did get about the suspected outbreak were from the media. They were received at 10.30 in the morning. Immediately we took action to confirm with the New Zealand authorities whether those reports were correct. I am advised that by 12.30 p.m. on the 12th all necessary precautionary measures were in operation in all Australian States. It must be emphasised to the House that it is not uncommon for simulated exotic disease exercises conducted by veterinary authorities in various countries of the world to be incorrectly reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Mr Speaker, as the practice regarding questions without notice requires members not to ask detailed questions which can be put on the Notice Paper, surely it is proper practice under the Standing Orders that instead of a Minister reading his answer he should either seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard or alternatively have the question put on the Notice Paper so that it can be answered in the proper way. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Since the time when the important work of the national population inquiry reached some unexpected conclusions about our population prospects, there has been a greater awareness of the need for continuing monitoring of the underlying trends. Accordingly, the Government has decided to present periodic reports to the Parliament and to the community in general on current and prospective demographic trends and on some of their implications for the Australian community. I have pleasure in tabling now the first such report entitled 'Review of Australia's Demographic Trends'.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the attention of honourable members to some of the main points in the report. Australia's population growth rate fell during the 1970s from around 2 per cent to a little above one per cent in 1975-76 before increasing to 1.35 per cent in 1979-80. About two-thirds of the growth in recent years was due to natural increase with the balance being the net effect of overseas migration. Births declined from 272,000 in 1971-72 to 227,000 in 1976-77 and have levelled out at around 223,000 in the past two years. Throughout the 1970s, the net reproduction rate, the most common summary measure of population replacement, taking into account both fertility and mortality trends, has continued to fall from 1.39 per cent to 0.92 per cent by 1979. This is 8 per cent below the long term replacement level. The most likely future is that Australia's net reproduction rate will continue to decline at least until later in the decade. However, even if fertility rates were to recover to around replacement level, it would be well below levels Australia has generally had in the past.

During the early 1970s the net population gain through migration generally declined. This trend has now been reversed with the net gain in 1979-80 being 82,000. Whilst there may be variations in future levels of net gain, the broad trends in the characteristics of Australia's population can be illustrated by population projections using a long term average annual gain through migration of 0.5 per cent to 0.6 per cent of the population. On the basis of the present population, this would be equivalent to a net migration gain of 73,000 to 88,000 annually. On these assumptions, it is likely that Australia's population growth rate will increase from about 1.4 per cent per annum over the next few years to about 1.5 per cent per annum in the second half of the 1980s, before declining to about 1.2 per cent by the end of the century. The population at the end of the century would be about 19,500,000, some two million more than it would be without a contribution through migration.

Significant changes in the age structure are anticipated between 1980 and 2001. Whilst the total population is expected to increase by a little over 30 per cent, the number of people aged 65 and over is expected to increase by about 70 per cent by 2001, whilst the number aged nought to 14 years is expected to increase by only 20 per cent. Following the variations in the annual numbers of births during the late 1960s and 1970s, there will be substantial fluctuations in the numbers reaching primary, secondary and tertiary education ages, calling for flexibility in manpower and infrastructure arrangements in education. There will also be significant fluctuations in the numbers of young people entering the labour force. For example, the number of 18-year-olds is expected to increase from a trough of about 250,000 in 1984 to a peak of around 290,000 in 1989 before declining to around 250,000 again in 1995.

The declining birth rates mean that there will be a general ageing of the population with the median age being likely to rise from 29.5 years in 1980 to about 33 years at the end of the century. This may result in the labour force becoming more experienced but less mobile. Lower occupational and geographic mobility makes it harder for the economy to adjust to structural changes and the introduction of new technology and increases the social and economic costs of moving people to new development projects, particularly in remote areas. Whilst migration will not halt the overall ageing of the population, it can change the dependency ratios by bringing in younger people. For example, on current assumptions, the proportion of the population in the 65 and over age group is expected to be about 12 per cent by 2001. With no net gains from migration, a figure of about 13 per cent would be expected.

The changing age distribution of the population also has implications for industry. The general trends in market growth will be away from products for teenagers to products for the over 30s. Growth in demand for products for the older age groups is expected to be particularly rapid.

Persons in the older age groups are of particular interest to policy makers. Whilst the number of people 65 and over is expected to increase rapidly, this growth is even more pronounced at older ages. For example, the number of persons 75 and over is expected virtually to double by the end of the century. The absolute size of these groups affects social welfare planning, including the provision of pensions and special medical care and accommodation.

These are some of the major population trends and implications. Whilst they may not appear to raise immediate issues, we must remember that demographic trends take generations to work their way through a population. We should not be misled into believing that issues arising from future population developments can be left to the future. We need to remain aware of these developments so that they can be taken into account in planning for the future. The matters covered in the 'Review of Australia's Demographic Trends' are very important long term issues. I commend the review to the House. I present the following papers:
Australia's Demographic Trends Review-Ministerial Statement, 25 March 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words on the matter instantly, although I understand that the Government intends that it be discussed later in the session. Further discussion of it is certainly warranted. I believe the make-up of Australia's population, together with the decisions which have to be made in regard to immigration to Australia, are of enormous importance because there is not one facet of Australia's planning that is not affected by the decisions which we make in relation to the future population of this country. It does not matter what area people are involved in-whether it be social security, health, local government, education and so on-we should be looking ahead as to how the lifestyle and the lives of Australians are going to be affected by decisions which are made now.

We did have a minor discussion in the House some time ago on the question of immigration and the future population of this country. I said that it seemed to me to be an enormously important aspect of discussion in this House that the two major parties which can govern this country should come as near as possible to the same point of view. I have no reason to change that statement, because if we are talking about the future education standards of our people, about meeting the great challenges that might lie ahead over the next 20 years or 30 years, which is not very long in the life of a country, or about any other matter people need to know now what they are to be catering for. As the report points out, under certain circumstances, using certain criteria, much of which could be altered in the next 10 or 15 years, Australia at the turn of the century could have a population of 19 1/2 million people. We are not sure, for instance, what will happen as a result of the movements to and fro of New Zealanders. We are not sure of the demands which will be made upon Australia in terms of taking our share of refugees from whatever countries they may come from. I think the economy being what it is and the economic demands being what they are in the home now which have brought about a resurgence of married women going to work it is unlikely that we will see an uptake in the fertility rate in Australia which will markedly alter the figures given to us in the statement made today by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee). South Australia, with a very narrow economic base, could be affected in 15 years time to a greater extent than it has over the last 10 years. We have to look at where the placement of population is going to be. I believe it is of great significance, when we are looking at the welfare area, to recognise the great increase that there will be in the number of people who will be retired and the burden that will be placed on taxpayers in looking after those people. We have an acknowledged but not a universal retiring age of 65 years. I do not believe 65 years will be the retiring age in this country for much longer. I believe the retiring age for working people will be lowered and I think this will come upon us very rapidly just as I believe the shorter working week-I do not want to get into the arguments about that-will be a reality for all people in the not too distant future. Those sorts of developments and changes will mean that planners will need advanced advice about what they should be doing.

We can see that there will be a transfer of people who have reached retiring age. They will want to head into areas in which they will have a more comfortable lifestyle. Perhaps they will want to live in places which have warmer weather. However, the demands upon the services in such places will really be enormous. The report deals with migration from the States of Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania to Western Australia and Queensland. Some of that migration is traditional in the case of retired people, who like to go to where the weather is warmer. Some of that migration is contemporary in terms of the jobs which may be available. The report deals also with the fact that as the Australian average age rises over the next 20 years, the majority of people will be aged between 29 and 33, and they will become less mobile. The Australian work force is already described as being immobile. If we become any more immobile, there may be greater demands on migration in order to fill the jobs wherever they may be, sometimes in remote areas. This raises extremely important questions about what will occur in this country. As I have said, there is no doubt that people in the welfare area will have to plan ahead for what will need to be done for the greater percentage of people who will have no earning capacity and who will have to be kept by the people who are still working, and what that means in terms of the taxation burden which will be placed upon those working.

It seems important also that this House ought to give consideration to having a standing committee on the subject matter contained in this report so that we can be kept up to date on the demands which will be made on structures within Australia. It may be that the report has reached conclusions with which the majority of the people in this House do not agree. It may be that the majority of people in Australia want to see migration lowered. It may be that there are people who would rather see Australia, through its government agencies, encourage a rise in the fertility rate. Some countries are concerned about the number of people in their work forces. Countries in Eastern Europe have moved to try to encourage larger families, but this has not worked. Women not only find it comfortable to go to work but also in the majority of instances they have to go to work to maintain the home or to maintain the standard of living which they expect to be able to provide for their families. I think that the report raises a number of very important questions which ought to be discussed in this House. I sincerely hope that the Government brings it back quickly for discussion.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Fraser Government and the Foreign Investment Review Board to protect the national interest by not involving itself in the initial equity arrangements for mineral projects at the authority to prospect stage as evidenced by the present controversial decision by the Queensland Government when awarding the Winchester South coal lease to a consortium headed by British Petroleum Ltd.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) I indicate-this is not said in any sense as a rebuke, because the matter as raised is in order-it would be of convenience to the House if proposals for the discussion of matters of public importance could be put in shorter terms. I make that statement to all members of the House who may be raising matters of public importance in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has proposed this matter of public importance because of the continuing alienation of national resources to foreign companies and to governments which own those companies, particularly in the climate of questionable mineral tendering processes such as we have witnessed in some States and, more recently, in the State of Queensland. Last week we saw the Bjelke-Petersen Government award an important coal area in that State, which is worth about $2,000m in current prices, to a consortium headed by a foreign oil company which is 46 per cent owned by the British Government, without the Queensland Cabinet examining the other 32 tender proposals which had been placed before it, without the Queensland Cabinet knowing the detail of the successful tender proposal and without the Queensland Cabinet making the details of the successful tender proposal public. If the tender was so good for Queensland and the National Party in Queensland believed that the State was being advantaged by the acceptance of the tender, why was the tender not published so that the people of Australia could see just how good it was? Of course, we have seen no publication of the tender. In fact, we have seen reported on the front pages of the Queensland newspapers very terse comments by the Queensland Premier attacking that person in the Cabinet or within the Government who dared to leak the puny Cabinet submission which dealt only with the one tender document.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have witnessed is yet another corrupt mineral lease arrangement in Queensland, decided not by the Queensland Cabinet but by the National Party organisation without resort to fair and open practice, fair and open tendering processes. As we indicated in our outline of the matter of public importance, the problem is that the Commonwealth is left right out of this procedure. Because the States have had the constitutional prerogative to issue mineral licences where they have seen fit, when we want to pursue a national policy of maximising Australian ownership-we have an interventionist foreign investment policy as a result of that-we find ourselves in the position of the Federal Government and the Foreign Investment Review Board being left to ponder the arrangements after they have been decided by the States, in this case by the Queensland Government.

Whilst the BP consortium has 51 per cent Australian equity-that is well within the present guidelines-we have reached this very sorry state in the administration of our affairs that nobody cares about 100 per cent Australian equity, or any level of Australian equity in excess of 51 per cent. Whilst the Government has been dragged screaming to the 51 per cent barrier and whilst it now on occasions, particularly in mineral leases, is trying to abide by the 51 per cent policy, the situation is virtually this: If a company comes along with a 100 per cent Australian equity proposal it is virtually obliged to let the Government know who its foreign partner is. So instead of having a minimum 51 per cent policy we have a 51 per cent policy per se. In the case of Queensland not so long ago we had the Queensland Premier bleating about takeovers of Queensland companies by companies from the south, yet apparently the Queensland Government does not mind surrendering large tracts of coal in Queensland to foreign companies. One wonders what the motivation is.

However, the most important factor in the awarding of this Winchester South lease area to this consortium headed by BP is that, from the knowledge we have, no up-front money was offered by the BP company or the other companies involved; and that includes Thiess and the Westfield company, which are part of the successful consortium. Some 32 consortiums applied for this lease area, many of which were exclusively Australian. Yet the offer by the successful consortium does not have any up-front money; it has only a royalty off the top after production starts. Any Australian company could have offered a royalty after production starts. One would have thought a rich international company or a consortium of rich companies would have been able to offer an up-front amount of money, as is the case with competitive mineral tenders in Canada and other parts of Australia. But that is not the case in this situation. What we see in this is a normal State royalty and then what is called a super royalty which operates after start-up. When we looked at what the super royalty was we found that it was $1 a tonne, escalating to $4 a tonne by the year 2005. Taking into account just the inflationary portents in that period, a quick calculation reveals that the $4 a tonne will be worth 50c.

What was special about the BP tender? The former Minister for Mines and Energy in Queensland, Mr Camm, was escorted or hosted on a trip overseas by the BP corporation after he retired as Minister. The dogs were barking the fact that the BP, Thiess or Drayton and Westfield offer would be accepted despite the fact that other tenderers had spent up to half a million dollars competing. In one celebrated case we saw a number of young men in Queensland resign from international companies to get an Australian consortium together. They have been rejected and no one knows why. Yet we find that Mr Sullivan, the Minister who replaced Mr Camm, was not in the job for long enough. When the Queensland election came along he was replaced as Minister for Mines, Energy and Police. He held the post for five months. Quite obviously, one has to ask the question: Was it because he dug his toes in and indicated to the Premier that he would not go along with that shonky process of awarding the BP consortium rights over Winchester South before the formal tendering processes had been before the Cabinet? Mr Gibbs was then appointed Minister for Mines, Energy and Police.

It is alleged that the successful consortium has been invited to donate to the Bjelke-Petersen fund; that is, a fund which sets up investments in Queensland, the earnings of which maintain the party machinery of the National Party. If that is the case it is corrupt. If it is not the case the company involved in the consortium should say so. I invite BP, Thiess and Westfield-God knows how Westfield, a property developer, got involved in this-to indicate whether that money in fact was sent on to the Bjelke-Petersen fund. The other 99 companies and 32 consortia have been knocked back. Apparently some companies have offered to the South East Queensland Electricity Board coal at cost in the future as part of their proposals. Apparently another tender proposal offered to build a power station without any charge to the public. We have had no explanation of why those proposals have been rejected. We have heard Sir Robert Sparkes, the President of the National Party in Queensland, saying that because someone dared to leak the scandal which is behind the issue a royal commission ought to be conducted into the leak.

We find that the Queensland Treasury was not even involved in the process. It was only when it got an inkling of the fact that the matter was going to Cabinet that it muscled its way in. We are told in the media and elsewhere that no economic benefits of any kind over and above the normal royalties and taxes would have flowed to Queensland from the BP-Thiess-Westfield tender had the Treasury not tried to improve the tender. After that we saw a report in the Australian Financial Review of 24 March, a copy of which I have here, headed: 'Queensland Government backs down on leaks between royalties, CPI'. The article states:

Despite the efforts of its Treasury, the Queensland Government yesterday abandoned its attempt to inflation-proof the super-royalties which will be paid by the BP Australia-led consortium which will mine the big Winchester South steaming coal prospect.
Instead, State Cabinet has agreed to accept BP's original offer of a royalty rising in set steps or a charge related to the selling price of the Winchester coal on world markets.

If the tender was complete, what was the point of the Queensland Cabinet or its Government or the Treasury as its agent trying to do a deal after the tender had closed? The whole purpose of the competitive tender is to determine, on the basis of the offers, which is the competitive tender and to make a choice, not to go back to try to sew up a deal to inflation-proof the miserable royalty which will end up being worth 50c a tonne in 20 years. This is a scandalous situation which the Federal Government should deplore. I expect that when the Treasurer (Mr Howard) responds to this matter he will deplore the situation and will do the decent thing.

Some wonder why Australians feel there is a need for a Federal resource rent tax. Of course there is a need for it. How could anyone hope to marshal the wealth of this nation for Australians while those brigands in Queensland who run the Queensland Government give away the nation's resources in a scandalous and squandering way? Mr Sullivan, the Minister, had the hide to say in Cabinet that the consortium would offer the Australian public an opportunity to take up shareholdings at the appropriate time. Everyone knows when the appropriate time will be; it will be after the consortium has done some exploration drilling and quantifies the reserve. That is when those companies will offer the mugs, if you like, of the Australian investing public-the companies regard them as mugs-shares at a huge premium. Instead of the Australian public getting in on the ground floor at the exploration or authority to prospect stage they will be given a chance to invest after BP, Thiess and Westfield have had a chance to quantify an area which they already know is coal bearing. Then and only then will Australians other than the Australian shareholders involved in the consortium have a right to a shareholding. Even then it will be at a premium which suits the companies which are selling. What the consortium will end up with will be a carried interest in the project for next to nothing while the Australians pay the premium. Do honourable members think it is reasonable that BP or even Thiess or Westfield should reap those kinds of benefits? I do not believe it is reasonable.

Something else Mr Gibbs did was virtually to threaten unsuccessful applicants not to release the details of their tenders lest they be treated harshly in the future when next they submit a tender for consideration by the Queensland Government. Sir Robert Sparkes, the Tammany Hall crook who runs the National Party, came out and said that there ought to be a royal commission into the leak. How dare the public find out about this corrupt practice!

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. It is both unparliamentary and verging on being cowardly for the honourable member--
—I withdraw the imputation.
—There is no point of order.

—I withdraw the imputation. I am interested to see the Treasurer defending Sir Robert Sparkes's activity here. Sir Robert Sparkes is saying that there should be a royal commission to determine who leaked the document. The document was leaked in the interest of truth and to expose the corrupt practices within the Queensland Government. We want to know what is happening and why. I think these questions should be answered. I think BP, as one of the successful tenderers, should make public its arrangements with the former Minister, Mr Camm. I think the company should reveal its tender documents and so should the consortium in general. It should tell us how and why it came to make arrangements with Thiess in the first place. It should tell us particularly how it made arrangements with Westfield. It should tell us why a company which is half owned by the British Government should be subverting-if it is-the legal tendering processes of a government in Australia to secure a rich resource over which it would otherwise have had no prior claim.

SPEECH.PARA: In all this the Fraser Government fails to act; it is powerless. The foreign investment rules as they are administered do not get down to the matter of authority to prospect. What happens is that the Fraser Government faces under its foreign investment regulations a fait accompli situation when these consortia have made their equity arrangements and have proven reserves beyond the authority to prospect stage. Then and only then does the Commonwealth involve itself. If the Commonwealth is interested in decent practices in terms of the awarding of rich coal bearing areas or mineral areas in the country which belong to the people of Australia it should be involved particularly in relation to investments at the authority to prospect stage and not wait until these resources have been hacked about, traded at all sorts of premiums. Just before the companies start to mine they trundle up to the Foreign Investment Review Board and the Treasurer is then in the position of trying to make some kind of sense, to make a silk purse out of a sow's ear, after the thing has been ripped and raped by all the speculators who are caught up in it or who happen to know the people who run the Queensland Government. It is a scandalous state of affairs. We have not seen anything as rough as this in a long time.

To think that the Queensland Government was deluged, as few governments are, with all these commercial offers for a very large lease of steam coal. Steam coal is one of the most sought after products in the world. It should not just be handed away. It is a public resource which should not be handed away to companies which happen to know the Queensland Premier, which kick into a National Party fund or which are mates with Sir Robert Sparkes. That is what is happening in this country. We want to know what the Fraser Government will do about it. I will be interested to hear the Treasurer condemn the awarding of this tender and let us know what he intends to do about the fact that 100 per cent Australian-owned consortia have been rejected in this auction in Queensland. Australians are disadvantaged to the advantage of foreigners-not just foreigners but companies which are substantially owned by a foreign government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) did himself less than justice today. I have heard a lot better from him on the subject of foreign investment in the past than we heard from him today. Predictably he spent most of his speech making wild, unsubstantiated allegations against the Queensland Government. Let him support the accusations of bad faith, the accusations of favouritism and the accusations of corruption that he has made. It was only the great tolerance of the House and you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that allowed him to spend most of his time talking about decisions that are essentially quite outside the province of the Commonwealth Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to award the authority to prospect to the BP-Westfield-Drayton consortium was a decision taken by the Queensland Government and one completely within the legal province of the Queensland Government. The honourable member for Blaxland and every other honourable member opposite knows as well as we on this side of the House know that the Commonwealth Government has no power whatever to stop any State government, be it the Queensland Government, the Wran Labor Government in New South Wales or indeed any other State government around Australia, from making a decision as to who is awarded an authority to prospect. I listened for quite a while to see whether there was any connection at all between the foreign investment responsibilities of the Federal Government and what has happened in respect of this coal project. It was only at the end of his speech that the honourable member for Blaxland finally said that what the Federal Government should really do is to apply its foreign equity guidelines at the authority to prospect stage and not at the exploration stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sure.

—I am glad that the honourable member for Blaxland acknowledges that because it would appear on the surface-without in any way pre-empting the consideration that the Foreign Investment Review Board has to give to this project-and on the published information that the BP consortium meets the foreign equity guidelines because it is at least 50 per cent Australian owned. On the logic of the honourable member for Blaxland, if we applied foreign equity rules further down the line, back to the authority to prospect stage, this project, on the evidence so far available as far as foreign equity is concerned, would meet that guideline. On the score of equity levels this consortium has at least 50 per cent Australian equity.
—Order! The honourable member for Blaxland had the opportunity to address the House. He ad- dressed the House and was heard in silence. It is now his turn to remain silent.

—The honourable member for Blaxland does not like being reminded of the principles of a foreign investment policy which he on a number of occasions in the past has said enjoys a certain degree of bipartisan support in this House. That has certainly been the position not only of himself but also of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) who, when addressing a seminar in Western Australia about 18 months ago on foreign investment, said that there was a great deal of bipartisan support. Let us have a bit of consistency on this issue. Let us remember that not only does this consortium have 50 per cent Australian equity but so also indeed did the consortium that was granted the authority to prospect for the Curragh deposit in Queensland some months ago which also was the subject of criticism from the Opposition. That consortium also had 50 per cent Australian equity.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, it is not my intention in this debate, nor is it my responsibility, to pass a judgment on the decision of the Queensland Government to grant this authority to the BP-Drayton-Westfield consortium. I do not know all the circumstances of that matter. I expressly make it plain that I am not competent to pass a judgement on that decision. I am competent to make it very clear to the House that that was a decision made by the Queensland Government in full exercise of its authority in those matters. The Queensland Government had a 100 per cent right to take whatever decision could be taken in the circumstances so far as the granting of an authority to prospect was concerned. In that way its powers and the exercise of its powers were no different from the exercise of powers of any other State government. Indeed, numerous examples exist around Australia of State governments having granted authority to prospect in the teeth of fierce competition from a significant number of tenderers. The honourable member for Blaxland, as I understand his motion, would invite us to change the foreign investment policy so that questions as to whether the equity rules are met are asked at the time an authority to prospect is granted. If that is the policy of the honourable member, and he nods assent, he has forgotten what happened a few years ago when a Labor government was in office. He has forgotten the effect of that kind of approach upon exploration in Australia.

That policy might work-although I regard it as being undesirable on general foreign investment grounds and make that plain on behalf of the Government-with less difficulty in certain areas, but he knows very well that in regard to oil exploration it would cause considerable difficulty, as it did between 1972 and 1975. One runs the risk that such a policy, if applied, would create those kinds of difficulties again. Of course, there can be legitimate debate about the type of foreign investment that a country can have. This Government is not totally blind to legitimate proposals in regard to its foreign investment policy. It does not claim that in every respect that policy is perfect but, by and large, over the last five years it has brought a degree of consistency, predictability and fairness to the development of this country's resources. We have been able to achieve that often difficult balance between the need to attract large amounts of foreign investment for the development of our resources and the need to ensure that Australians will receive a fair share of the action.

It is a strange irony that we should be debating the merits of a coal project in Queensland when, in respect of coal projects in Queensland, this Government has demonstrated more firmly then it has on any other issue its absolute determination to keep to the foreign equity guidelines and to ensure that Australians can participate fully in our resource development. I remind honourable members of the Government's insistence in respect of both the Blair Athol and Oaky Creek coal projects, two of the largest that this country has seen, against the criticism, I acknowledge, of the Queensland Government-criticism that the Government will continue to reject as not soundly based-that Australians will get a fair share of the action. But let us not lose our sense of perspective. Because we have now created an environment which is more conducive to domestic and overseas investment, because we have created a climate in which there is a good balance between the two objectives that I have mentioned there is no occasion to begin altering, willy-nilly, our foreign investment policy and to strive towards the attainment of objectives which might meet some theoretical goal but which, in reality, would produce a great deal of consternation and disturbance about our foreign investment policy. The existing approach, which holds that the equity guidelines must be met at the production stage rather than at the exploration stage, represent an appropriate balance. It represents, if I may put it, a trade-off between Australian participants paying a higher premium for later entry and our taking advantage of the greater willingness at the exploration stage of overseas companies to invest. All these issues involve matters of judgment and balance. In respect of our foreign investment policy, the goal of achieving the overall balance of which I have spoken is best attained by requiring that the 50 per cent guideline be met not at the exploration stage but rather when production begins.

We are referring here, of course, to the development of Australia's coal reserves, one of our most valuable resources. I remind the House that since 1976, under the foreign investment policy of this Government, 16 new coal development projects have been examined. Of these, 12 have met the 50 per cent equity guideline. Two are required to meet the guideline when production commences. Two have not been approved but are likely to be resubmitted with due regard to the 50 per cent rule. I ask honourable members: Does that represent a selling-out of this country's resources, an abnegation of the Government's responsibility in regard to foreign investment? Does it represent anything other than an entirely sensible and consistent approach to resource development, recognising that we must attract overseas capital to help develop Australia's resources?

The Government will yield to nobody in ensuring that Australians get a fair opportunity to participate in the development of Australia's natural resources. That is written into our foreign investment policy and will be applied without exception. But in defending that approach we will not blind ourselves to what foreign investment has done for this country. Unlike the Labor Party, we do not shrink from acknowledging the contribution of foreigners to Australia's development. In the same way as they helped to build a local car manufacturing industry when no one else was interested in doing so, they have participated, and will be allowed to participate, in our resource development. It is the height of absurdity and unrealism to ignore the contribution that overseas companies have made to the development of this country and of its resources. One must have a mature, sensible and practical approach to the subject, a mixture which both takes account of the benefits of foreign investment and ensures that Australians have an opportunity to participate on fair terms. That has been the thrust of this Government's policy over the last four years and will be its thrust in the future. On those grounds, I believe that the production stage is the appropriate stage at which the guidelines should operate. That maximises in the most practical and efficient way the benefits of foreign investment, while leaving it open for Australians to participate.

Therefore, the Government rejects the notion that the guidelines ought to be altered in the manner argued for by the honourable member for Blaxland, who spent most of his time not really talking about our foreign investment policy but about a decision that is not within the province of this Government-or a Labor government if it were in office-to make. The decision was made by the Queensland government. I do not know all of the circumstances and the honourable member for Blaxland has failed completely to substantiate any case for an alteration in the foreign investment policy of the Government, which has worked to such great benefit for the Australian nation.
