I appeal in particular to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and to the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick)-since the Treasurer is in the chamber I will appeal to him also-to instigate an investigation into all decisions taken by the Queensland Government with respect to resource and mining development in Queensland over the past five years. That is very necessary. If this Government wants to put its razor gang to work to get some more money for the Treasury it should undertake such an investigation because Joh is getting away with murder. The Government knows it, and all Australians know it. The Australian Government and the Australian people are entitled to a better deal and to more money. The money should not go overseas or into the pockets of the wealthy people of Queensland.

The five decisions the Government should investigate are: The siting of the Tarong power station, the granting of authorities to prospect to former Ministers of the Crown, the Queensland Government's refusal to release details of the Winchester South tenders, thereby concealing the fact that tenders other than the successful tender offered better deals for Queensland, and the Queensland Government's failure to reveal the full facts relating to the expenses of the former Minister for Mines and Energy, Mr Ron Camm, on his overseas tour organised by the British Petroleum company. It is an alarming situation about which we all should be concerned. It is nothing other than a national scandal and a cover-up. I intend to prove that, and I intend to prove to the Treasurer that we can get more money if we take a little notice and interest. I know the Treasurer has explained that it is very hard to handle Joh, and he must be very worried now that he has one of Joh's closest relatives as a member of his Government. She will tell all the secrets. He is finished now, and I know that all Government members are running scared.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the honourable member's attention to the fact that he is not free to reflect on any member of the Parliament. He may proceed, bearing that in mind.
—I did not think I reflected on anyone.
—The Chair sees it as a reflection.

—I am saying how the Treasurer is running scared. I think the Prime Minister is, too. I refer to the granting of the lease to the British Petroleum-Theiss-Westfield group. I believe I speak on behalf of all Australians when I say that Australians have a priority interest in knowing how the Queensland Cabinet arrived at the decision to allocate a prospecting authority over a $1,600m coal field. The lack of answers to a number of questions strikes at the very heart of the concept of honesty in government. For instance, why should British Petroleum have thought it necessary to host the former Minister for Mines, Mr Ron Camm, on a trip overseas before he retired last year? British Petroleum dominates the successful Winchester South consortium. The Australian public should be told if that company knew at the time it organised Mr Camm's trip that tenders were being invited for the right to prospect and mine coal reserves worth $1,600m. We might all like to know why Mr Camm and Sir Leslie Thiess, while in London, met with British Petroleum officials. That is another interesting question. I wonder what happened at that meeting. I wonder why the British Petroleum company and Thiess were told that if they included Westfield in the deal, they would be sure of the contract.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other inferences to be drawn from the fact that a man known to many people, and known well to the National Party, was at the head of this deal. I do not like naming people in the Parliament, but the matter has been reported and I think it is necessary that it all be cleared up in this House. The man is known to be Sir Edward Lyons. Sir Edward Lyons knows very well that he is being accused of these things. If the truth has to be known and the deals have to be put on the table then Sir Robert Sparkes, who wants everyone's name cleared, should clear the name of Sir Edward Lyons, too. His name is mentioned in dispatches, along with all these other accusations. They cannot all be wrong; they are not all made up by the Labor Party. They are made up by the Liberal Party, and honourable members opposite well know that.

The coalition Government in Queensland is very shaky at the moment, and it will be shakier from here on in because of the leaks. If honourable members opposite condone these actions, I can only feel sorry for them. They can only be condemned for doing so. As the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) has said, Mr Camm's successor, Mr Sullivan, did not last long in the job. Why was his tenure cut short? Was it because he declined to use the rubber stamp again? He knew all about the rubber stamp Government of Queensland. A report in the Brisbane Courier-Mail of Wednesday, 11 March states:
Mr Bjelke-Petersen said he reviewed the tenders last week, and the winning tender was 'so far ahead of the others there can be no argument about it.'

What a lot of nonsense that is. There can be no doubt about it because he had rubber-stamped it. He had gone to Mr Gibbs, and said that he would give him the job if he would rubber-stamp the issue. Everyone knows that that is what happened, and that is why Mr Sullivan, another honest Minister, got the chopper. Plenty of honest people get the chopper in the Queensland Parliament. Why was the consortium's bid pushed so hastily and with such great secrecy before a Cabinet which had no prior knowledge of the merits of this or other tenders? My time has run out. However, many more accusations have been made. Unfortunately I will not have time to put them before this Parliament. I hope that the Treasurer will take some action in regard to this matter and that he puts the razor gang to work in Queensland very quickly, especially so far as Bjelke-Petersen is concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It must be a grave disappointment to this House to have before it a subject which is so lengthy in its presentation but which is spoken to so little from the floor of the House. One wonders why the Labor Opposition has raised the matter. I can give only one reason-that the Labor Opposition in Queensland is so lacking-it is non-existent-that it has to forward the charge to Canberra for the cream puffs of this Opposition to take it up. I have no hesitation in defending the National Party of Queensland for its role in the coalition Government. It must be remembered that that coalition, of which the Liberal Party is the other partner, has developed the State of Queensland. It is doing that partly on foreign capital and under the guidelines of the Federal Parliament. I ask the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys) whom he supports-the old guard at Breakfast Creek, the new guard at Charlotte Street or just the rearguard of the Opposition in Queensland?
—It is probably the mudguard.

—As the honourable member for Bowman said, it is probably the mudguard, and that is fairly rusty too. Let me deal with some of the unsubstantiated charges that are being made in connection with the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation. I imagine that exactly the same criteria apply to that as applied to the John Curtin House when it was established a decade or so ago. I deny that there has been any corruption. The Foundation is sponsored not by the Queensland Parliament but by a political party. Accusations of corruption are beyond credibility.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also appalled that the opportunity has been taken to try to use parliamentary privilege in this place to cast a slur on the character of some very fine Queenslanders. Sir Edward Lyons, who was mentioned by the honourable member for Griffith, is a fine man and I believe that he had no part in the assessment of tenders or the letting of the contract for the Winchester South coal deposits; nor did Mr Camm. Mr Camm was a Queensland public servant at the time. I understand that he had no part in it whatsoever. The claims that he had anything to do with the acceptance of this tender are unsubstantiated. I hope that the public of Australia sees this as a very weak and futile attempt by the Federal Opposition in Canberra to take up the cudgels for a very weak Opposition in Queensland. I think that had to be said.

As I said, the argument has been narrated as a long one, but the question must be: So what? This is a constitutional matter. Queensland has certain constitutional rights. We know that the Australian Labor Party, as a Federal party, would want to deny resources to the States and take them for itself. As far as I can see, this matter of public importance is not being raised so we can debate the subject in question but it is being used as a diversionary tactic to knock the multinationals or the transnationals and to promote the Opposition's argument in favour of some form of resource tax. We know that the Opposition wants to expand the coal levies it implemented between 1972 and 1975. It wants to impose a resource rent tax. It wants to put further controls on industry from Canberra, whether it be through the Foreign Investment Review Board or not. It wants to direct and not guide the policies of resource development in Australia. I think we have to be aware of the actual intention of the Opposition in bringing this matter up.

In bringing this matter forward the Opposition has shown very little enthusiasm and has provided little information to back its claims. For instance, has the Opposition talked about applying Australian ownership guidelines to prospecting? I do not think that it has been mentioned in more than two or three words. Certainly the honourable member for Griffith said nothing about it at all. But it favours such guidelines at the developmental stage. Why do we not let the foreign capital be used in prospecting provided-this is still the proviso with the Winchester South field-that at the time when the developmental lease is negotiated we do have Australian capital?

It is interesting that the last report of the FIRB indicates that between 1974 and 1975 the degree of foreign ownership of the coal resources of Australia was 62.1 per cent and foreign control was 64.1 per cent. In 1979 the figures had dropped to 40.3 per cent for Australian ownership and 43.5 per cent for foreign control. The report also indicates that for new black coal projects the projected production is 127.7 million tonnes per annum. It is contemplated that 35.1 per cent will be foreign owned. So the percentage is decreasing.

A rather spurious argument was advanced by the member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) when he said that resources owned at the moment by foreign interests could be sold at a substantial premium later. This Government would not want to control the transfer of shares to the extent that was contemplated by the honourable member for Blaxland. One company floated in Australia, the Southern Pacific and Central Pacific Minerals Co., was 100 per cent Austalian owned. I would like to know what degree of Australian ownership there would now be and how loyal the original Australian shareholders have been when the price has fluctuated overseas. How can we control such things?

The Winchester South field, which is in the Dawson electorate, is one of a number of steaming coal developments. On the admission of the Labor Party, I understand that the project must be about 75 per cent Australian owned, particularly as BP Australia is in Australian hands. There were 32 applicants for the Winchester South lease. I understand that the matter was taken to Queensland Cabinet without details being given to the Ministers beforehand, as is normal over a weekend because of security. I understand also that Cabinet appraised the matter and made its decision in the normal way. A fat lot of good that security precaution was. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition in Queensland was able to bring leaked documents into the Parliament. But what a leak it was. It was just a damp squib. The Queensland Opposition was so unsuccessful that the Opposition's mouthpieces here, the powder-puffs of the Parliament, have had to take up the cudgels.

It is important to recognise that coal resources are State-owned assets. The control the Commonwealth has over them through export licences and the Foreign Investment Review Board is sufficient. The Winchester South project is likely to return to Queensland more than the other projects have in the past. I think that is only to be expected when the history of coal mining development in Queensland is traced. In the past there has been a high degree of foreign ownership when developments have commenced, but foreign ownership is decreasing tremendously. On the face of it, why can we not let the multinationals undertake development in a very high risk area, which is what resource development has been in the past? Now the Government of Queensland has proved, as it did under the direction of the former Minister for Mines, Mr Camm, that it can progressively pick up more in royalties and State taxes as development goes along. It can benefit not only through government revenue but also through Australian participation. Our guidelines are to the effect that wherever possible Australian development should be in the hands of Australians if they can afford to put up the money. But if a development is to lapse for want of Australian funds, it is then that we should seek foreign ownership. We are talking in terms of only 25 per cent Australian ownership in this case. I believe there is nothing irregular. I believe there was tremendous lobbying and tremendous pressure from the 32 other applicants before the decision was made. I agree with the security arrangements that were implemented, but which were not successful in view of the leak. This Parliament-the Opposition and the Government-would seek maximum Australian participation, as it has, and that it would want to get maximum Australian revenue, as it has in this case. I agree wholeheartedly with the Treasurer in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night, the effluxion of time cut me off in my prime. I was proposing a case for the Australian Tourist Commission to be upgraded to the status of a full department. I mentioned some of the reasons why that should happen and I spoke briefly about the financial significance of the tourism industry, its labour intensive nature and my view of the Government's lack of a real understanding of the importance of tourism to Australia. I would go further and suggest that the chance to create jobs in the leisure industry by sensible forward planning by government would be a prime justification for bringing back the Department of Tourism and Recreation. Tourism will grow in response to increased leisure time, annual leave and rising real incomes. The 35-hour working week is inevitable, despite the sabre rattling against it by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). As Voltaire said-I am sure a man of your erudition, Mr Deputy Speaker, would know this quote-'no army can withstand an idea whose time has come.' The time has come for this Government to be much more aggressive in its promotion of tourism. Were the Government more prescient than stubborn, it would concede the merits and the inevitability of the 35-hour week and swing into a progressive strategy to maximise the resultant leisure boom that will come out of shorter working hours. This is just not happening.

SPEECH.PARA: The tourist industry needs a great deal of Federal Government assistance. Many competing interests have facets of the tourist industry within their ambit; for instance, caravan manufacturers vying with motel proprietors, airlines in competition with coach companies right up to States versing States, all in competition for the leisure dollar. So a scheme to promote tourism generally would be difficult for private industry to undertake. The only real alternative, once we have decided just how important the tourit industry would be, is government funding. This is a prime example of public sector spending directly stimulating demand in the private sector. I would like to make this reservation in proposing a federal department to oversee tourism and leisure. I would not like to be seen to be ignoring the existing Australian Tourist Commission or the fine work it does. I am merely stating that the fine work that it does merits its being upgraded to departmental status.

I mentioned in my earlier remarks that the Government's net contribution to tourism in the last Budget was $10m. This parsimony on the part of the Federal Government belies its much heralded support for the tourist industry. I would like to quote the Chairman of the Australian Tourist Commission on the problems that he is having with staff ceilings which have been drastically reduced in the last few years. He said that staff ceilings 'caused extreme difficulty in adequately servicing the industry overseas'. The Chairman went on that this was in spite of the dedication of the staff who were 'very keen and highly enthusiastic' and worked long hours, deferring leave and other private commitments in order to achieve the goals they had been set. There is no need for slave labour to capitalise on the tourist boom. A separate department is the logical answer. The Commission, I might say, is very optimistic about the future growth prospects for inbound tourism. Although it does not expect the high growth of 1978-79 to continue into the 1980s it does predict a rate of about 13 per cent per annum-a very considerable figure.

I would suggest that under the auspices of a ministry we could get down to the very serious business of government involvement in the tourist industry. Of course, whenever the term 'government involvement' crops up we hear shrieks of 'socialism' from some quarters. Yet, as I argued previously, through government involvement the industry can function to its maximum capacity and efficiency being, as it is, fragmented and yet, so economically significant. I do not know why we fear this proven strategy. It has been proved overseas that if governments become involved in the tourist industry that involvement usually leads to prosperity. In the last 12 months I was a member of a government delegation to Mexico. The Mexican Government could not, by any stretch of the imagination, be described as socialist. I can tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, of the beautiful hotel at which we stayed in Mexico City-the best hotel in a city of 14 million people. That hotel-the Chapapultic Hotel-is owned and serviced by the Mexican Government. The New South Wales Government is presently involved in the building of the Sydney Regent in the Rocks area of Sydney. It will be the finest tourist hotel in Sydney and will provide immediately 300 full time jobs. I think that is fairly representative of what can happen if the Government is speculative, entrepreneurial or dynamic in promoting a tourist industry in Australia.

It is ironic that the great northern crusader against the dreaded socialists, the husband of Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen, saw fit to hand over part of Queensland freehold to Japanese interests, namely, Iwasaki, but steadfastly refuses the same privilege to Australian Aborigines. They have to be content with a lease. Mr Deputy Speaker, whilst you might consider that what I am saying is fairly tenuously involved in this tourist argument, allow me to say this to you: 'I think the Iwasaki project could have gone along with a 50 per cent government involvement, with the Australian people still holding the freehold'. I think that is exactly the way in which the Government should be operating. Of course, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) spoke a while ago about this Government's allowing BP to have the Winchester lease in Queensland although this organisation is 46 per cent owned by the British Government. Yet, the Government refuses to involve itself in any sort of promotion of that type for fear of being branded socialist. I find that situation to be rather invidious.

I would like to explain further how I think the Government should have involved itself in the financial sense. I was recently on the Gold Coast. I note that the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) at the table is from Queensland. I was told by the Gold Coast City Council about the dreadful trouble it is having in providing proper facilities in that area. It is very short of money which is needed to keep up proper water and sewerage services. It appears that each luxury unit in all the complexes which are presently being built right along the coast, particularly at Surfers Paradise, provides only $140 a year in local rates. That seems to me to be a very poor state of affairs. The people who own and live in these units have access to the beautiful beaches on the Gold Coast for only $140 a year. I think there would be a very good case for this Government to slap a luxury tax on those sorts of developments to ensure that money is provided so that local government can properly service those areas. After all, they are our future.

The only industry in Australia which appears to have some prospects in the labour intensive areas is the tourist industry. Unless governments of all sorts have the money to invest in the industry our hopes for the tourist industry will not be realised. The same thing that is happening on the Gold Coast is happening in Sydney. Areas such as Bondi and Coogee are known world wide as the great attractions in Sydney. The only money that local governments get to keep those beaches looking reasonably decent is from the local residents. It seems to me that governments should make subsidies available so that these facilities can be made the sorts of attractions they should be. Bondi is pretty chatty by anybody's estimation. I see the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Jull) is shaking his head, but it is true. If the Federal Government were prepared to subsidise those beachside areas with some funds perhaps they could be made the Acapulco of Australia and perhaps attract more tourists than they do.

We have golden opportunities to make and take from the exciting leisure industry. The Minister for the Capital Territory and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr Hodgman) said that we can expect a record one million tourists to Australia this year providing a $1,000m boost to the economy. We cannot talk up a boom. It we did it might be dangerous to the economy. We must underpin the tourist industry with sound and sensible infrastructures. We on this side of the House urge the Government to stop pussy-footing around and to come to grips with the true situation. We have great potential as a nation which is attractive to its own citizens to explore and equally attractive and interesting to foreign visitors. We must do all in our power as a government to foster the industry to the advantage of the Australian population, not forgetting the sensitive nature of our environment. The two are capable of existing harmoniously with forward planning of the right kind.

I will leave it to later speakers in the debate to refer to the great attractions of Australia. I know that the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) is anxious to tell us of the glories of the cosmopolitan city of Sydney. He will want to say something about its beautiful harbour and its magnificent Opera House which is attracting something like 90 per cent of all international visitors. We will be told about the Great Barrier Reef in Queensland, the uniquely Australian town of Alice Springs, the Red Centre, the Alps and the whole range of beautiful natural attractions which we have in Australia that are not properly exploited.

In urging the Government to take up our suggestions I leave honourable members with this thought in mind. I refer to a quotation from The Complete Life by John Erskine-a book which was written a long time ago. It states:

The body travels more easily than the mind, and until we have limbered up our imagination, we continue to think as though we had stayed at home. We have not really budged a step until we have taken up residence in someone else's point of view.

I put it to the House that our view is worthy of the Government's mental residence. I hope that it takes up our suggestion that by being more aggressive, more entrepreneurial and more dynamic in the promotion of the tourist industry, by means of some government involvement in terms of revenue, this industry which has enormous potential could prosper in Australia so that the resources boom, which inevitably we are going to have, will lead to shorter working hours and a greater possibility that the Australian population will enjoy all the wonders of Australia. In doing so we would provide employment for other people because this is the one industry in Australia which is capable of promotion and which is entirely capable of providing employment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think one of the features of the great debate on tourism in the last Parliament was the fact that both sides of the House took a bipartisan approach to the subject. The honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) played a very real part in helping in the development of tourism for Australia. I was a little disappointed in some of the speeches, especially in the speech of the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) last night. He seemed to forget that bipartisan approach and was terribly critical of some areas on which, frankly, he did not have the facts and figures. Perhaps I should spend the first part of my contribution to this debate today in stating exactly what the situation is.

SPEECH.PARA: More has happened in tourism in this country in the last five years than happened in the previous 25 years. Australia has increased its share of international visitors. I believe that last night the honourable member quoted the figure of 0.03 per cent. That figure has risen to 0.07 per cent, which represents not an insignificant number. He did admit this afternoon, however, that this year for the first time we are looking at the prospect of having one million international visitors to this country. That is indeed significant. We are fast heading to the time when Australian tourist accounts will be in the black. Previously we have had an outflow of dollars. Australians going overseas spent more than tourists coming in. It is significant that tourism receipt figures are rising. On present estimates, this year we can look forward to receiving $900m from international tourists. That is incredible. The latest figures which have come to hand would indicate that the average overseas visitor last year spent something in the vicinity of $1,013. That is a significant figure.

This year tourism will be worth in excess of $386 billion world wide. It is the second biggest industry after the oil industry, and by the middle of this decade the tourist industry will be as big as the oil industry. Thank goodness that Australia is now starting to take its share of that international tourist market. We have been able to do this for a number of reasons. It is true that the amount of money spent overseas by the Australian Tourist Commission has increased substantially. That has certainly helped. The lowering or partial lowering of international air fares has also helped in increasing the number of visitors coming here. But the real fact of the matter is that Australia now has become more competitive in international tourist terms. The fact that we have been able to keep our inflation rate lower than that of most of our competing countries has been significant. For example, the walk in off the street price at an Australian hotel is now appreciably lower than the prices which are charged in places such as Singapore or Bangkok. It is infinitely cheaper than the United Kingdom price and infinitely cheaper than prices in most of the countries of Europe and it is on a par with prices being charged in the United States. We can compete. Australia is a very desirable destination.

Certainly the Australian Tourist Commission has a huge job to undertake. I think it does that job manfully and well with the resources that it has. I would not disagree that there is room to move in expanding the budget of the Australian Tourist Commission to help it in its promotion. At the moment it is limited by the number of overseas officers and the number of staff that it has. Those things being taken into account, the Commission is doing a magnificent job. As the honourable member for Parramatta pointed out, we must continue to support and develop this industry because it is this industry more than any other which provides job opportunities, especially for semi-skilled and unskilled labour. As I have said in this House, and I think it is worth repeating, the Bureau of Industry Economics has proved that for every extra 25,000 international visitors coming to this country another 1,400 jobs are created. That is a most significant figure. The evidence is already there; it is already working.

A very interesting study is being undertaken in Queensland at the moment. Last year, in terms of job growth, Queensland outpaced all other States. In excess of 30,000 new jobs were created. It would appear that the tremendous boom in Queensland tourism has brought about an absorption of so many of those unemployed about whom we are all concerned. This can be directly attributed to the tourist and other allied industries and I think we must continue to promote such development. Another interesting thing is that domestic tourism has become more competitive in recent years. Having taken their first trip overseas, Australians find on their return that it is now cheaper to holiday at home than it is to take an overseas trip. We are certainly competitive in that regard. It is cheaper now to take a holiday on a Great Barrier Reef island than it is to go to, say, Fiji. It is certainly much cheaper to do an Australian tour than it is to go to some of the Asian destinations. When we consider that last year we experienced occupancy rates in some of our hotels along the Queensland coast as high as 91 per cent, that speaks for itself. The boom is on at the Gold Coast. It is certainly on at the Sunshine Coast around Noosa and at Cairns. Frankly, it is magnificent. However, there are things that need to be done, and there are things which we must move on very quickly if we are to take full advantage of that international tourism boom.

I think one of the most significant things that the Government has introduced is the depreciation allowance for new hotel construction. Right now around Australia no fewer than 27 new hotels are under construction. It is estimated that this year in Queensland alone $600 billion will be invested in the tourist industry. That is a significant figure. A few years ago the industry was in a state of depression and tourist operators were going broke. It is almost unimaginable to think that with just that little bit of Government help we have now reached the stage at which $600m is about to be invested in Queensland.

I should like to turn to a couple of the aspects of the amendments to the Australian Tourist Commission Act which we are debating today. These amendments give the Australian Capital Territory the opportunity to have a full voice in terms of the decisions of the Australian Tourist Commission. That is important. I am certainly not a Canberra-basher. Canberra is a very significant tourist destination. It has tremendous growth potential, especially for international tourists. The figures which were released in recent days are interesting. They show that the second biggest tourist attraction in Australia after the Sydney Opera House is the Australian War Memorial. Tourist operators in Canberra can give us significant figures as to the increase in the number of international tourists going through Canberra, especially in the inclusive tour charter coach market. These tourists are staying in Canberra in excess of one day and the amount of money that they are spending in this city is significant. It would be very interesting indeed to do an analysis of just which is Canberra's biggest industry after the Public Service. From my knowledge, and from speaking with the tourist operators, it would seem that tourism is Canberra's second biggest industry. For that reason, the Australian Tourist Commission should have representation from the Australian Capital Territory. It should also have full representation from the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —A new airport wouldn't do any harm.

—I could not agree more. Airports are very much a key to the success of the industry. I should like to get on to the aviation side in just a moment. In terms of the Northern Territory, it was interesting to learn from the studies undertaken by the ATC, that the two most desirable destinations that people want to visit in Australia are the Great Barrier Reef and Ayers Rock in the Northern Territory. We must make every effort to make sure that we meet the requirements of our international visitors. I am sure, with the amount of money that is being spent by the Northern Territory tourist promotion people at the moment, and with their input into the Australian Tourist Commission, that that can be brought about and that there will be a promotion of the unique facilities that are being offered in the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: It would seem to me that there is only one thing that is holding Australian tourism back at this time. That is certainly our international air policy which is married, of course, to our domestic air policy. I mentioned a moment ago that the institution of the advance purchase excursion fares system has helped significantly in generating people coming to Australia. The figures that were released following the survey of international visitors indicate just that. I pay full tribute to the Government for bringing in that measure. That experiment has not worked fully. International air fares are becoming detrimental to the inflow of tourists to this country. Our biggest single problem at present is probably not our physical position in the world. As someone once said, no longer is Australia's problem the tyranny of distance; it is the tyranny of the high air fare.

I think we should go back over the last three years to see exactly what has happened. The new air fare regime was heralded in many places as being the great salvation for Australian tourism. I admit that we have seen dramatic increases in the number of people coming to Australia to visit friends and relatives. We have seen quite good increases in the number of pure tourists coming to this country. If we look at where those pure tourists are coming from on their package holidays we will see that our biggest single international market is New Zealand. Because of our old links and old ties we should be looking more towards Great Britain and Europe providing us with international visitors.

I accept that there has been a dramatic increase in the number of people visiting friends and relatives. Frankly, I was quite shocked and horrified to find at recent public hearings on applications for air routes into Australia that the total number of package holidays sold to Australia from Great Britain last year was 2,000. Britons are the largest purchasers of package holidays in the world. In fact, last year five million Britons went overseas on package holidays, and Australia got 2,000 of them. What is even more horrifying is that British Airways, which has a monopoly situation with Qantas Airways Ltd on the Australian run, actually allocated a grand total of 20 seats a week to travel operators in Britain to sell package holidays to Australia. If that was not enough, with just a little over 100 people coming here on British Airways, it was later learned that Qantas contributed the princely sum of 700 seats during the year to travel operators to package Australian holidays. The rest of the package holidays were sold, probably on bodgey fares, by the Malaysian Airline System. MAS contributed more to the package holiday market in Australia last year than either of the national carriers operating on those two routes. We were told by Qantas and especially the Department of Transport that when the new international air fare regime came into operation it would be the greatest thing to promote tourism.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. The Chair is reluctant to interrupt the honourable member but I point out that it would be helpful if he made more frequent references to the Bill before the House.

—One of the things with which the Australian Tourism Commission is charged is looking after the promotion of Australian tourism and operating in conjunction with the airlines and the Department of Transport to encourage international visitors come to the country and to travel around the country. The point I wish to make is that there must be a closer relationship between the Australian Tourist Commission and the aviation authorities in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: When the new air fare regime was introduced three years ago we thought there would be more flights, cheaper seats and cheaper fares. Let us look at the history of the route. I have spoken to Australian Tourist Commission officials in London who have given to me much of the information and have detailed many of the problems with which they are faced. They have produced some facts that really are quite startling. Although promises were made not one new flight has been introduced. Apart from the ten flights that were operating in 1978 not one new flight has been introduced by Qantas or British Airways on that route. International passenger survey figures indicate that 40 per cent of the traffic on the United Kingdom-Australia run is taken up by intermediate point traffic-the high yield traffic. Only one new Australian city, Darwin, is being serviced under this new air fare regime. That service was introduced only after a speech was made in this House in which Qantas was severely criticised for failing to serve Darwin. Services to Sydney and Melbourne have remained unchanged. Services to Brisbane operated by the two national carriers have been depleted. The service to Perth has deteriorated from 12 to 10 services a week and, at the moment, the super-Apex fare is not particularly low.

In terms of the tourist related fares being operated on world routes the cheapest air fares to Australia at the moment are exactly twice those being charged on the major routes. The advance purchase air fares are subjected to those conditions to such an extent that Qantas actually advertises in the United Kingdom trade Press that seats are not available. We are told that that is a matter of commercial judgment for Qantas. If we ask the Department of Transport how many Apex seats are allocated they say that that is a commercial secret, that we are not allowed to know. I doubt whether the Australian Tourist Commission would know the number of seats allocated. Quite frankly, some of the figures I obtained in Britain were really staggering. Those figures show that as few as 15 seats to Australia were allocated on the cheaper fare.

Neither of our national carriers has really done much to promote true tourism traffic to Australia from Great Britain. The Australian Tourist Commission should have a much greater input in determining aviation policy. I spoke to people in the Australian Tourist Commission in London who said that their greatest frustration was in getting seats to make available to travel agents in Britain to provide package tours to sell to Australia. Frankly, that is just not good enough. It is fair to say that we cannot expect the Australian Tourist Commission to provide miraculous figures unless all the conditions are right. To my mind that would be the one point that needs to be rectified as soon as possible. We have to get that air fare component right in an international sense. I find it amazing that we were told three years ago that negotiations were under way to establish a tour basing fare between Britain, Europe and Australia. That tour basing fare has not yet come about. The negotiations have not been successful.

We have reached a situation in which officials of the Department of Transport are sneaking around the place, checking out passengers' tickets to see what is happening in the cut price air fare war. All that Australians are doing is reacting to the free market forces. I cannot see why an Australian traveller should have to pay twice as much as air fares should be. It is a lucrative market. I can blame no one but our own officials and perhaps this Government for setting up a protectionist area that has failed. We can only expect the free market forces to work. They will continue to work until such time as we take Qantas out of its quandary and let it compete in the market-place. Once we do that Qantas will absolutely kill the market. The Chairman of Qantas has already indicated that he is prepared to compete in the market-place. It is important that we get that absolutely right.

At the moment the domestic aviation situation also is in a state of flux and some very hard but very real decisions have to be made by the Government in the next few weeks. We have a new airline agreement. That agreement has been negotiated by the Department of Transport, the Government and the airlines but there has been no input regarding the terms of that agreement by the Australian Tourist Commission or the tourism section of the Department of Industry and Commerce. One wonders when one approaches the Department of Transport or the ATC just how much notice is taken by those bodies anyway. The problem with which we are faced is that we now have in Australia a cozy club in which Ansett Airlines of Australia, Trans-Australia Airlines, Qantas and the Department of Transport go behind closed doors in a secretive manner and negotiate air services. It is about time that those negotiations were brought out into the open. I suggest that this could be done by establishing in Australia some sort of authority which issued air licences and adjusted fares. If we could do that we could get the very real input of the ATC and the tourist industry into the whole decision-making process.

One of the questions that has to be asked by this Government in the near future is: 'How far can we go?' The fact that a tour basing fare is not available for Australian based travel agents from domestic airlines certainly is causing problems within the domestic industry. Travel agents in Australia receive only 5 per cent commission and we are reaching a stage where it is not in their best interests to try to promote Australian travel or Australian domestic fares. It is not in their interests to get good packages together so that they can be sold overseas. This is the sole prerogative of the domestic airlines. Unless the Australian Tourist Commission has the facility to package Australia in the best possible way we will never realise our true potential. We must realise our true potential if for no other reason than the tremendous employment prospects offered by international tourism. I support the amendments contained in this Bill. The Bill will be a tremendous help in promoting the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory as true parts of the total Australian holiday package experience.

SPEECH.PARA: Figures were given a few moments ago by the honourable member for Bowman indicating the expansion of the hotel industry. TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Minister is here.

—The Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr Hodgman) is here. It is like having the twelfth man. There are serious problems. I ask this House to listen to what I am about to say because I believe we have to overcome these problems. If we take the right action there will be even more exciting times ahead of us. In Australia vast numbers of tourist towns see themselves as the tourist mecca. That will not occur. We cannot develop hundreds of tourist villages in Australia. We have to be relatively selective in promoting and planning specific areas for tourist development.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also a growth in the number of aged people moving to the same tourist areas to retire. This has meant that there are hundreds of thousands of aged people moving into some towns, creating a conflict of interest between the retired and the business community which is seeking to increase the tourist traffic. The benefits of tourism-increased shopping and recreational facilities-often are not perceived as benefits by the retired, who resent the intrusion of the tourist, whom they regard as an intruder. Increased rates enable local government to provide infrastructure-water, sewerage, paved roads and cultural and social amenities. As the retired are, in the main, no longer seeking employment, the most obvious benefit of tourism is of little interest to them. The less obvious indirect benefits often are not related by them to tourism. Each new attempt to increase tourist attractions and accommodation is resisted. It is also true that in many cases the two lifestyles come into direct conflict. A very large number of tourists look for excitement on their annual vacation. Hotels, restaurants, bars, sporting events and facilities may well delight the tourist but in the numbers required for a successful tourist resort they may be anathema to the permanent resident, particularly the retired. Quite a number of tourist villages and towns are now resisting or at least questioning the large-scale tourist development that is being planned in their regions. Yeppoon, Noosa and Cairns are a few examples. We ignore this problem at our peril.

A feature of Australian tourist development is that in earlier times the rush to encourage development led local councils to accept virtually any application providing they increased rate revenue. Approved by councils were subdivisions which did not have water, sewerage, drainage and paved roads; facilities alongside poorly built shopping centres, and which lacked adequate community cultural and recreational centres. Although councils are now lifting their standards, in some areas the damage has already been done. Many seaside tourist and retirement areas are blighted by the past lack of planning and aesthetic standards and are too costly and fraught with administration difficulty to redevelop. Cheap, shoddy fibro and weatherboard holiday cottages alongside fading prefabricated jerry-built shopping centres have given many areas reputations that they are finding it difficult to recover from.

There are some notable exceptions such as Surfers Paradise, Port Macquarie, Coffs Harbour and Cairns which have attracted quality developers who are investing in international standard accommodation and tourist attractions. However, even these areas suffer from the mistakes of the past when earlier administrations lacked a vision of the future. I often give my own area, the central coast of New South Wales, as an example of that. There is also a marked reluctance by major hotel groups to become involved in tourist development outside the major capital cities. They prefer to concentrate on the business traffic in the cities. Earlier I mentioned the development at Parramatta by the South Pacific group. I have a great admiration for the South Pacific group but it has not been prepared to develop in the wilderness areas. Earlier I mentioned the hotel which is to be built at Parramatta. I appreciate that it is a business decision, but it is a shame the South Pacific group has not done so.

Developers are now seeking unspoiled areas to develop quality tourist resorts demanded by international visitors. Once again a clash occurs as Australian residents resent their intrusion. Noosa appears to be a particularly good example of this sort of clash of interests. Conservation groups are alert to any further alienation of the coastline, having seen so much degradation in the past. Tourist development is equated with the worst sort of coastal mismanagement. If Australia is to compete with the resort development that is occurring in other parts of the world where whole towns are being built for tourism where previously nothing existed then it is essential that total tourist complexes are developed along with existing centres and in tune with the environment. I think that can be done but we have to recognise this problem and separate, in some instances, the retired and local population from the tourist complex itself.

Opposition to total tourist development is often misdirected. Alienation of the coastal environment is occurring, whether we like it or not, by a number of kilometres each year. It attracts little attention because it is so gradual and occurs in so many small projects. I could never understand the opposition to the Yeppoon development. We have had problems-I will not go into them now-but I thought it was an excellent concept. Australians who have sought peace and tranquility for vacations or retirement are entitled to have that uninterrupted. However, if Australia is to attract international visitors and encourage Australians to spend more time holidaying in Australia, we must develop international quality tourist resorts for those who want a more active holiday, including sporting facilities, nightlife, restaurants and man-made attractions. Different people seek different things in holidays and I would be the last person to say: 'This is the sort of holiday you should have'. If people want nightlife and restaurants, let them have it. If they want to camp in the bush, that is fine. We should not impose one standard on everybody.

At the moment Australia has only one town totally planned for tourism-Thredbo. Another project of a similar nature being planned is the Yulara Village at Ayers Rock, and I compliment the Government on that project. The Iwasaki development at Yeppoon is, of course, in the same category. How do we resolve the problem caused by the lack of tourist facilities? In my view, Australia must build planned tourist developments to match what is happening in other parts of the world. Bali, Fiji, the Philippines and Mexico are just a few examples of countries which have set out after the tourist dollar and are going about it in a thoroughly planned and professional manner.

I want to talk about Mexico which was mentioned in this debate by the shadow Minister. The best example of a properly planned tourist development that I have seen is in Mexico. The Mexican Government has created a body, the National Trust for Tourist Development, which is known as FONATUR. It was established in 1974. It plans and builds, in co-operation with private enterprise, international standard resorts. Last year I visited two projects, as a guest of FONATUR, at Can-Cun and Ixtapa-Zihuatanejo. Can-Cun is located on the Yucatan Peninsula in the Caribbean near the ancient Mayan cities of Tulum and Chichen-Itza. It was selected after a search of 10,000 kilometres of coastline to find a remote area suitable for tourist development that offered all the essential requirements for discerning tourists-climate, scenery, beaches and proximity to places of historic and cultural interest.

FONATUR operates similarly to our own National Capital Development Commission. It acquired the whole area, 10,000 hectares, for total development and moved in to provide the infrastructure required for Can-Cun to attract the private investment necessary to ensure its success. The resort is on an island about 21 kilometres in length and 400 to 500 metres at its widest part which is separated from the mainland by only a few hundred metres or so. The local director of the Can-Cun FONATUR project informed me that about $75m had been invested in the infrastructure costs of the township alone. The Trust had already received all that money back from the proceeds of the sale of land to private developers and hoteliers. I was not able to obtain details of the total cost of the international airport, telecommunications or road developments, but this was probably about a further $200m.

The whole area is planned to ensure that there is maximum harmony between the tourists and the local residents. Hotels and condominiums, residential areas, shopping centres, the airport, convention facilities and the commercial centre are all located in properly planned areas to ensure ease of movement and aesthetic standards. The project has been developed in stages. At the moment it has reached the 4,000 hotel-room mark and is well on the way to establishing 10,000 rooms. Virtually all the major international tourist hotel chains are represented, including Hilton, Sheraton, Club Mediterranee, alongside the Government's own chain, El Presidente. Twelve months ago private investment was estimated at between $350m and $400m in five or six years. Public and private investment, therefore, is probably between $600m and $700m. It needs to be remembered that the Can-Cun development is in a remote part of Mexico well away from the developed communities. It could be compared with our building in the Gulf of Carpentaria. I was informed that no existing communities were in the immediate area.

Figures on the development are very interesting. In the few years since Can-Cun was established, its growth has been phenomenal. The 4,000 hotel rooms have an occupancy rate of 89 per cent. In 1979 Can-Cun received 400,000 visitors-five years after its establishment. Fifty per cent were domestic visitors and 50 per cent were foreign visitors. Of the 50 per cent foreign visitors 82 per cent were from the United States and most of the remainder were from Canada. The city of Can-Cun, which has no employment other than tourism, has created employment for 9,000 people. If we include the families of those people, 36,000 people gain a living from tourism there. In 1979 those 9,000 employees earned an average of $US40 a week. That may not seem much but it was about 30 per cent higher than the earnings of the average Mexican. One hotel room in Can-Cun provides food for 10 Mexicans.

Although FONATUR sells land to private developers for hotels, motels and so on, it retains tight control on the type of development that occurs. Mexico has some of the finest and most imaginative architects in the world. This is evident in the design of the hotels which clearly bear the mark of the early Mayan architecture. Every private development proposal has to be passed by FONATUR. That does not mean only the physical dimensions. Unless the sketch plans are aesthetically pleasing and fit in with the overall design, they are sent back to the developer to be redrawn. No conflict exists between high-rise and low-rise buildings because the two areas are separate. Special zones are created for hotels, condominiums and private residential areas. The main commercial administrative centre is located well away from the main resort area. Light industry also has its own region.

I also visited Ixtapa-Zihuatanejo which is on the west coast, about 200 kilometres from Acapulco. This project is a smaller version of Can-Cun. It has about 1,500 hotel rooms and is aiming for a total of 5,000 rooms. I liked it better because I thought it was more in keeping with the sort of thing we could develop in Australia. Can-Cun was a bit grand for us. Ixtapa-Zihuatanejo is an area similar to the Cairns area with tropical rainforest and mountains in the background. It is absolutely beautiful, beautifully planned and it in no way interferes with the local community.

—I think the honourable member is right. The development is financed by government and initiated by government but in total is a private and public enterprise operation. The Government gets its money back by selling the land to private enterprise and private enterprise knows the project will be fully promoted because the Government has a large investment in it. TERMS OF REFERENCE
The Terms of Reference of the Inquiry are as follows:

1. The Inquiry is to examine air fares on the trunk routes and regional routes operated by the two major domestic airlines, Trans Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia, with special reference to the way in which fares are set on individual routes in the national network by use of an air fare formula.
2. In respect of these routes the Inquiry should report, and make recommendations as appropriate, on:
(i) costs, revenues and load factors,
(ii) existing and alternative pricing policies including special discount arrangements,
(iii) the degree of cross-subsidisation.
3. The Inquiry shall have regard to:
(i) the public interest,
(ii) government domestic aviation policy including the objective of increasing competition,
(iii) the effect of competition on fares,
(iv) the report of the Domestic Air Transport Policy Review Committee,
(v) the desirability of a nationally consistent approach to setting first, economy and standard class fares,
(vi) factors which affect operating costs on particular routes,
(vii) the assignment of corporate overheads,
(viii) operations of other airlines over routes referred to in (l),
(ix) other relevant factors.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. For example, in the year 1979-80 passengers on the Perth-Sydney sector subsidised passengers on other routes to the extent of some $8.8m. If this cross-subsidisation is going on it helps to explain why many tourists from overseas, upon landing at the gateway of Sydney, for example, do not venture any further west simply because they make the decision that the fares involved in doing so are simply too expensive.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point identified in the report relates to the deficiencies of the fare setting procedure. The committe considered that the very existence of cross-subsidisation was a serious indictment of the existing pricing policy. That policy is based on the technically inefficient operation of the two participants, Ansett and TAA, in a system which in itself enshrines inefficiency. When tourists arrive in Australia the only way in which they can fly about the country in the major air networks is with these two airlines. One can appreciate that the cost of fares will affect whether those tourists travel further than the gateway of arrival. Throughout the report the committee brings down findings in similar vein. If people have the time, I would refer them especially to chapter 6.

Finally, the third point that the inquiry identifies relates to the lack of the accountability and regulatory control needed in such a regulated environment. The committee argues that where the two airlines are operating in an environment which is devoid of market forces and commercial considerations there is evident a lack of control which should be exercised by the regulatory authority-a control which should be exercised in the public interest, not only in terms of those who need to fly about Australia in the course of ordinary business but also of our tourist trade.

In response to those three major findings, the Holcroft report presents 36 recommendations which, taken as a complete package in the context of the two-airline system, represent an attempt to improve that system and better safeguard the public interest. I see as a first option open to the Government in considering the report the complete implementation of the 36 Holcroft recommendations. I do not think that it would be good enough to adopt only the fare setting recommendations and simply remove the cross-subsidisation inequities. It is the monitoring role and the need for public accountability which underpin the fare setting procedure. As I said earlier, these provisions are necessary to discipline the airlines in the absence of competitive market forces. Once again it demonstrates the point that fares are but a product of the system and cannot be considered in isolation.

If the Government were to pick up what I have labelled the first option in an effort to improve the situation two difficulties would be presented. Firstly, it cannot be implemented without substantial renegotiation of either the present two-airline agreement under which the system works or that which the Government hopes to bring in later in the session. For example, the necessary monitoring role of the regulatory authority and the increased public accountability that is called for by the report cannot be put into effect in conjunction with either the present or the proposed agreement. The 36 recommendations, taken as a package, represent an attempt to improve the domestic air fares situation to the benefit of regular commercial travellers, private travellers and tourists. But even if the Government in an effort to assist tourism were to pick up all 36 recommendations, we would end up with what Holcroft himself describes as a second best option. Holcroft examines the two-airline system, as indeed he must if he is to consider fares. In various parts of the report the conclusion is reached that the two-airline system operates as a barrier to competition; it is out-of-date; it is a system which enshrines inefficiency; one which promotes waste and one which provides for fares being higher than they could be if another system were to take its place. In short, in response to these findings, the committee states:
The inquiry feels that progressive deregulation of all but safety requirements is the preferred solution.

It is no secret that I support this conclusion. In September 1979, in this House, I attacked the two-airline policy and called for its scrapping. I have repeated that call on many occasions and will continue to do so, if for no other reason than it has important consequences, as the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Jull) pointed out, for Australia's tourism. That, in turn, has important consequences for employment in that service area.

I am opposed to the two-airline policy because, among other things-if we are talking of tourism this is important-it denies to entrepreneurs freedom of entry to the market, the ability to be able to present a package-based fare in an endeavour to cater for the tourist market. It denies to the Australian travelling public significant carrier choice and offers little realistic price value choice in terms of fares. I admit that the policy, as it has operated, has some benefits. These relate to flight frequency and an especially high standard of in-flight service. But I do not believe that those benefits outweigh the disadvantages, and they are provided to the travelling public at an inflated cost.

Earlier I called the two-airline system a piece of economic madness which is costing Australia dearly. Certainly it is costing Australian tourism dearly. It is one based on inflated costs due to enshrined operational inefficiency caused by an absence of real competition. A deregulated system, one more open to competition and to competitive market forces, would ensure that all features, not just frequency of service but most importantly price, would be based on, and responsive to, consumer demand.

I propose that the Government adopt the second option related to the Holcroft report. Briefly, I believe that it should pick the recommendations which relate to fare setting and the removal of cross-subsidisation. I believe that to be an absolute must. It is not an opportunity for the Government to bring in some new initiative, but simply for it to rectify a long-standing injustice and to remove long-standing inequities. Secondly, and fundamentally, I believe that the Government should give five years' notice of termination of the present two-airline agreement, as provided for therein.

When one compares the two agreements, present and proposed, side by side one can see some advantages in that which is proposed for freight, postal services and the like, but one also realises that it would enshrine the present system for a further 10 years and would have drastic effects for regional operators, who could play a large part in servicing the internal tourist market. One also realises that it would have severe disadvantages for Australian travel agents. Therefore, the Government should drop the proposed agreement and give five years' notice of termination of the present agreement.

During the five-year run down period prior to expiration-here I take up a point that the honourable member for Bowman made-the Government should establish a civil aviation type of authority with two specific roles. Within the restrictions of the present agreement the authority should monitor and regulate the airlines system a la Holcroft. A specialist body is needed because, as the Holcroft report correctly points out, to date the Department of Transport has not been capable of fulfilling that role. Secondly, that civil aviation type of authority needs to investigate and prepare for the progressive deregulation of our airline system at the end of the five-year period, with a view to bringing about ultimately one which will be truly competitive, responsive to consumer demands and needs, and one which will require all operators to be subject to commercial considerations and market forces. Mr Deputy Speaker, time has got away from me. I thank you for your lenience and hope to continue this debate on a subsequent occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Tourist Commission Amendment Bill proposes amendments to the Australian Tourist Commission Act 1967. I would like briefly to outline the proposed major amendments and to comment on them. Section 6 of the principal Act is being amended to provide for membership of the Commission to be increased from nine to 10 members. The additional member enables the States and Territories to have three members on the Commission on a rotational basis. This is a very desirable amendment, one which the States and Territories have been seeking for some time. If there were to be any criticism of the membership of the Commission it would be that there should be greater membership representation by the States and Territories.

SPEECH.PARA: Present membership of the Commission comprises members drawn from the tourist industry, the Public Service and the States and Territories in the following proportion: Six from the industry, one from the Public Service and two from the States and Territories. Because the tourist industry is such an important part of Australia's economy and because its growth is dependent on the involvement of State and Territory government, I suggest that the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) should give consideration at a later date to increasing the number of representatives from the States and Territories so that each is continually represented on the Commission. I believe it is desirable to have closer liaison with the States and Territories for a number of reasons which I will outline later.

The amendments to section 12 of the Act concern the disclosure by members of the Commission of any pecuniary interest that they may have in matters coming before the Commission for consideration. I notice that the proposed amendments, although requiring a disclosure of any pecuniary interest, do not require a member to refrain from voting on a matter in which he or she has an interest. If the Act provides for disclosure of such an interest it should provide also for a member not to take part in or to vote on the matter under discussion. It appears that there is only a subtle difference between the amendments to Part V of the Act, which deals with finance, and the original sections. Funds appropriated to the Commission by the Parliament will remain with the Treasury and be paid to the Commission when required instead of being paid into the Commission's bank account, as was the case previously. In other words, the Treasury will earn interest on unspent funds rather than the Commission. I have no argument with that intention. In summary, the amendments appear to be desirable. Apart from those few matters dealing with representation on the Commission and the pecuniary interests of members, I support the legislation.

I now wish to speak generally on the role of the Australian Tourist Commission and the value of tourism to Australia. The Australian Tourist Commission was established to encourage visits to Australia by people from other countries, as well as travel within Australia. It is therefore a very important organisation which can become the catalyst for much increased visitation to Australia and for increased travel within Australia. I say that it can become the catalyst because I believe in previous years the Commission has had insufficient funds really to get on with the job of promoting Australia overseas and of getting people to travel within their own country. The credit for the significant increase in visitation to Australia in recent years must go not only to the efforts of the Commission but also to the reduction in international air fares and a shift in overseas currencies. As a result Australia has been made more appealing to visit from an economic point of view. The Commission's expenditure budget has grown from $1.520m in the first year of its operation, in 1967-68, to $8.9m in the current financial year. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The table shows that the Commission's expenditure grew steadily from 1967-68 until 1972-73 after which, in real terms, it steadily decreased until the 1979-80 financial year. The table shows that although expenditure has grown almost sixfold since 1967-68, in real terms it has grown only slightly in excess of 1 1/2 times. If the expenditure budget had kept pace with the deflator index, the expenditure budget for the current financial year would have been in the order of $16m. Obviously there needs to be further massive increases in funding to the Commission if Australia is to increase its share of the very competitive tourist market. Additional funds could be allocated by diverting from Consolidated Revenue to the Australian Tourist Commission the $10m presently received from the gateway exit tax. It is not good enough for the Government to point to the increased growth in tourism to Australia over recent years as an excuse for maintaining funds at a low level because other factors have been the cause of that tourist boom. The enormous drop in international air fares a couple of years ago and changes in overseas currency rates have combined to make Australia a more enticing tourist destination for many overseas visitors. That is why during 1979 a total of 793,000 short term visitors came to Australia, an increase of 25.8 per cent over the previous year. In 1980 the number of visitations continued to increase, and 893,000 people came to Australia on short term visits. The growth rate between 1979 and 1980 dropped to approximately 12 per cent and unless we devote more funds to promoting tourism to Australia the rate obviously will drop further.

SPEECH.PARA: Tourism is big business to any country and some smaller countries rely on tourism for their basic wealth. It is estimated that during 1979 overseas visitors added $650m to the Australian economy. When we take into consideration the tourist and visitation pattern of movement within and between the States and Territories of Australia by our fellow Australians revenue to Australia from tourism is around $1,000m. In my State of New South Wales during 1979-80, domestic tourism generated 16.3 million trips, 83 per cent of which were within New South Wales. There is great potential for domestic tourism within Australia but the $300,000 set aside in the current Budget for the Australian Tourist Commission to promote such activity is insufficient to get across to Australians the message that they should see their own country first.

Almost half of the Australian people do not take a holiday away from their usual place of residence, so there is still a lot of promoting to be done if we are to realise the full tourism potential of our country. Many of these people, particularly low income families, cannot afford to go away on holidays. To help overcome that problem I believe the Australian Government should provide funds to non-profit organisations such as local councils and the Youth Hostels Association of Australia to enable the construction of low cost accommodation facilities for use by low income families and the youth of our community. I congratulate the New South Wales Minister for Tourism and the New South Wales Department of Tourism for the manner in which they have provided low cost accommodation facilities by funding, mainly on a dollar for dollar basis, organisations such as those I have mentioned. Over $1m has been provided in recent years by the New South Wales Government for the construction of such facilities.

The national capital of Australia, Canberra, needs such accommodation facilities so that school children and low income families can come to this great city and enjoy its splendours. As an Australian, I am proud of our national capital and no citizen should be denied the privilege of seeing our capital and seat of government because he cannot afford to pay for accommodation. It is our duty to ensure that this city and this Parliament are accessible to our fellow Australians. As a pilot project I commend to the Government the provision of sufficient funds to the Youth Hostels Association to enable the building of low cost accommodation facilities in the Australian Capital Territory for use by school children and low income families. Half a million dollars is all that would be required for the project.

Returning to the activities of the Australian Tourist Commission, I would briefly comment on the level of staff ceilings set by the Government. Those countries from which we attract the largest number of visitors-New Zealand, the United Kingdom, the United States of America and Japan-have been the hardest hit by staff cuts. In fact all those countries have had or now have less staff to promote Australia than they had in 1977. If we look at the annual report of the Australian Tourist Commission we will see a staff summary on the last page. It shows that in 1977 in the United States of America there were 13 staff members on the Commission but in 1980 the number had dropped to 11. In the United Kindgom there were five staff members in 1977 and that number remains the same today. In New Zealand there were five in 1977 but in 1980 that number dropped to four. In Japan the number of staff in 1977 was six and that number dropped to four in 1980. I think that summary shows that there is a great need in the Australian Tourist Commission for an increase in staff, particularly in those countries from which we have most of our visitors. It is a ludicrous state of affairs if the Government is genuinely expecting the Commission adequately to promote Australia in those countries. It is little wonder that the New South Wales Government has opened its own tourist offices with staff in each of those four countries I have just mentioned. I suggest that the Minister look at this as a matter of urgency, because we cannot hope to increase visitation from those countries without adequate staff for promotional and informational purposes. In my opinion it would be far better for the Commission to promote Australia overseas as a total country rather than allowing the States to promote their own areas on a purely parochial basis.

However, in recent years we have seen some of the States, including New South Wales and Victoria, promoting themselves overseas because of the inadequate level of promotional activity carried out by the Commission. I do not like this purely parochial promotion by the States, mainly because a lot of the promotional material does not place Australia as a whole in proper perspective in comparison to the State being promoted. One would think, by looking at some promotional material, that all the attractions and natural wonders of this nation are the preserve of some States. Some of it reminds me of maps of the world printed in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries by certain oriental countries which showed their own sizes in an inflated manner in an effort to distort their true influence in world affairs.

I consider, therefore, that the Minister should attempt to obtain agreements from the States and Territories that the responsibility for promotion of Australia overseas should rest with the Australian Tourist Commission. The States could then utilise their funds on internal promotional activities and on the improvement of facilities. Sydney, for example, is the gateway to Australia. In 1980, 571,000 overseas visitors, or 64 per cent of the total, entered Australia through that city. The reason is, of course, that the nation's birthplace has much to offer the tourist with both natural and man-made attractions. Careful planning by The Rocks Development Authority has now transformed the Rocks area of Sydney into an historical delight. The Sydney Opera House is, of course, the most popular tourist attraction in Australia, and the linking of that attraction with the Rocks area has made the harbourside and Circular Quay area of Sydney a marvellous and most self-satisfying tourist visitation area. The New South Wales Department of Tourism is to be congratulated on its many initiatives in promoting and servicing the needs of tourists coming to Sydney. The Department's new tourist bus service, which transports tourists and visitors to the major tourist attractions in Sydney, is proving to be of great success. The New South Wales Government, by the introduction of financial incentives and, I believe, a depreciation incentive which is available from the Federal Government, has been able to attract a number of entrepreneurs and convince them to build international hotels in Sydney, some of which are already under construction. These international hotels, numbering some eight in total, will provide by the mid-1980s an additional 2,500 rooms for use by tourists. With the continued increase in tourism they will certainly satisfy a need at that time.

Whilst I have been somewhat critical of the Government's lack of adequate funding of the Australian Tourist Commission to enable it properly to promote tourism to and within Australia, I do give due recognition to the fact that during the last two financial years expenditure by the Commission has doubled. In conclusion, I request the Minister to look at the suggestions that I have outlined. I urge the Government to make a greater contribution to the promotion of tourism so that the Australian economy and employment in Australia can be further improved.
