TALK.START.PARA: —The Human Rights Commission Bill is a piece of legislation which is not new to this House. Human Rights Commission legislation has been before the House of Representatives on a number of occasions. We are now debating what could be termed a reframed but not altogether new Human Rights Commission Bill. The first Human Rights Commission Bill was introduced into the Parliament by a former Attorney-General, the now Mr Justice Ellicott. That Bill was debated at length in 1979. Honourable members will recall that in 1979 the whole Bill was lost over an impasse between the Senate and the House of Representatives concerning the so-called Simon and Martyr amendments dealing with the abortion issue. The Bill now before the House is substantially the same Bill as that of 1979.

SPEECH.PARA: Adverting to the debate on the abortion issue, this Bill is different because those amendments which were the subject of so much bitterness were moved by the members concerned as private members; obviously, they had not been accepted by the Government and incorporated in the Bill which at that stage had been passed by the Senate. The validity of the amendments moved then is somewhat doubtful when one takes into account the fact that the amendments moved at that time by the Opposition suggesting that the human rights provision ought to apply to the States and Territories were opposed by the same gentlemen who moved their amendments on the basis of their belief that those amendments would provide a means of protecting the unborn child. Many of us did not accept the validity of their amendments as they had voted against the proposition that the human rights legislation should apply to the States. Without the acceptance of that proposition, their amendments in fact would have had very little application because the human rights legislation would not have affected State law.

Nevertheless, this Bill also is a weak Bill. The amendment which we will move to the motion that the Bill be read a second time adequately sums up our opposition to this legislation and the constructive proposals with which we would replace it. Firstly, we object to the fact that the Bill has no application to the laws and practices of the States and the Northern Territory. It is perhaps interesting in this context to look at the second reading speech which former Attorney-General, now His Honour Mr Justice Ellicott, made on 1 June 1977. The then Attorney-General referred to the fact that his initial proposal in late 1976 was for the establishment of a joint Commonwealth-State venture. He stated:

Under this proposal the Commission would have had power, amongst other things, to examine and report on Commonwealth and State laws and practices that were inconsistent with the International Convenant and it was proposed that individuals would be able to bring complaints affecting them to the Commission for investigation. It was proposed that reports of the Commission would be made by the Commission to all governments and it would then have been a matter for the relevant government, State or Commonwealth, to take any legislative or administrative action that might be appropriate to provide a remedy for any violation of the Covenant.

In other words, the initial proposal was that at least the Commission would have some power to inquire into the laws and practices of the States. Under the 1979 and 1981 legislation this would not be possible unless we were to have a very activist commission which was prepared to take a broad view of its powers. Under clause 9 (1)(c) the Commission would be able to report to the Minister on Commonwealth law or actions which should be taken by the Commonwealth on matters relating to human rights. It would be possible-I certainly hope it will be the case-for the Commission on its own initiative to suggest overriding Commonwealth laws in a number of areas, particularly in relation to Aboriginal rights.

The second of our major objections to this Bill is that it provides no judicially enforceable remedies of any kind. We all recall how what is now known as the Murphy Human Rights Bill of 1973 was vilified in a disgraceful and dishonest campaign to have it rejected. Now even Government senators agree on the need for judicially enforceable remedies. Senator Missen described our proposed amendment as very attractive. He said that there was very little in the amendment with which he did not agree. Most of the criticisms advanced against the Bill were sound, he said. But we note that he voted against the amendment. It is perhaps interesting to note the comments which Mr Justice Ellicott made on the role of judges on the introduction of the 1977 Bill. He stated:
I believe it is fundamental in a democracy that our basic human rights should be defined by Parliament and not by judges.

No one disputes that Australian courts and judges are conservative and reactionary, by and large more concerned with the preservation of the property rights of the wealthy than with the civil and political rights of individuals. However, passing a Bill of Rights does not mean that a parliament gives up its role in relation to human rights; it means that parliaments are prepared to say that there are some rights which are so basic that not even elected governments may take them away. As Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau put it, those rights depend on the outcome of no elections. It is those two matters-the lack of application to the States and the lack of enforceable remedy-which underscore the weakness of the whole Bill.

The Government has a litany of sins of both omission and commission in the human rights area. It is the most illiberal government since the Menzies Government of the 1950s and the Bruce-Page governments of the 1920s. However, no one would dispute that the majority of human rights violations have been and will continue to be perpetrated by the States. The Ellicott joint approach has failed and the Durack approach is simply to ignore the States. It is clear that only a Labor government will be prepared to take the step that will give us effective human rights legislation; that is, the enactment of Commonwealth legislation under the external affairs power, placitum (xxix) of section 51 of the Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a dangerous exercise.

—It is not a dangerous exercise. Human rights are never dangerous. The Minister is not frightened of even the voters in his electorate. The present Government, after signing the two important declarations on human rights-that is, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Convenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights-finally got around to ratifying the Covenant on Civil and Political Rights on 31 August last year. The terms of the ratification are quite extraordinary. There are no fewer than 14 objections to the Covenant. Perhaps the most contentious of all of those is the reservation relating to Article 50 of the Covenant. Article 50 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The provisions of the present Covenant shall extend to all parts of federal States without any limitations or exceptions.

Of course, in 1979 Article 50 was the subject of considerable debate concerning the non-applicability of the Covenant to the States. No other federation, West Germany or Canada for instance, has ever attempted a reservation based on federalism along the lines of the Australian reservation. It has been suggested that that reservation may actually be void or, at the very least, there will be problems of reciprocal arrangements between Australia and other nations which have made no such reservations. The point has been made by Mr James Crawford of the University of Adelaide that the Soviet Union could use Australia's reservation as a ground for arguing that Australia has no standing to challenge the Soviet Union's violation of the Covenant.

Among Australia's other reservations was the refusal to accept the application of the electoral principle of one vote one value. Even the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner) would not object to that. That is why we still seek the enactment of a Bill drafted along the lines of the 1973 Human Rights Bill. Such a Bill would apply not only to the Commonwealth and the State parliaments and governments but also to the courts themselves. Recently the High Court dismissed an application for special leave to appeal from a conviction on a rape charge received from a person named McInnis in Western Australia. In effect, a majority of the High Court said that whilst it was desirable that people be legally represented, the trial was not void if there was not legal representation. Such a decision would have been impossible under the United States Bill of Rights. So it is important that we realise that the Bill of Rights is an instruction to both governments and parliaments, as well as to the courts. It will be noticed that there is an obligation under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights that people before the courts be entitled to legal aid and be legally represented before any judicial tribunal. But we find a high court saying that it is not necessary.

I turn now to the differences between the 1981 Bill and the 1979 Bill. One of these matters is particularly relevant, that is the removal of the provision allowing an applicant's complaint to be dismissed on the grounds that the complainant did not have sufficient interest or concern in the proceedings. We are glad that at least on this small issue the Government has now seen the logic which it failed to see two years ago. The other matter concerns the requirement for disclosure of interests by members of the Commission, no doubt brought about in part by the fairly inadequate report of the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest. We have always found that report to be inadequate, but at least the subject of pecuniary interest is now part of the Australian legislative agenda. The major difference between the 1979 and 1981 Bills lies in the widening of the jurisdiction of the Commission to possible breaches of rights related to the Declaration of the Rights of the Child, the Declaration on the Rights of the Mentally Retarded and the Declaration on the Rights of the Disabled. Some people might see this simply as an attempt to diffuse the abortion issue. However, there is nothing in any of these declarations that is anything other than totally worthy. All children, the mentally retarded, and disabled people, should enjoy special protection under the law. I hope that perhaps even in a small way these amendments can do something toward that end.

In view of the fact that the work of the Commission will not be limited now to easily enforceable civil and political rights, but also to rights which may involve government appropriations and community resources in general, it seems strange that the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, signed by Australia in December 1972, and ratified in December 1975, is not included. Matters covered by the Covenant or by the Convention are spelt out in the amendment. These include guarantees of the right to form and join trade unions, social security, an adequate standard of living, work, physical and mental health, education, and to take part in cultural life. I refer to some of Clause 2 of Article 10 of that Covenant. It provides:

Special protection should be accorded to mothers during a reasonable period before and after childbirth. During such period working mothers should be accorded paid leave or leave with adequate social security benefits.

The Article then goes on to deal with other matters. I think it is significant that we have failed to embrace that Covenant in this legislation. In the Senate the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) did not reply on this issue. One would hope that the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, who represents the Attorney-General in this place, would at least seek from the Attorney-General consideration of that proposal.

The other matter which we seek to have incorporated in the Commission's jurisdiction is the United Nation's International Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women. In the Senate on 12 March, Senator Ryan gave notice that she would be moving a private member's Bill after July because of the Government's inaction in this area. Some of the States appear to believe that discrimination against women does not exist. In the Australian Capital Territory the whole subject is a long-running saga. At this stage there seems to be no reason, pending comprehensive Federal legislation dealing with discrimination against women, that the rather ineffectual Human Rights Commission should not be given jurisdiction over matters concerning the Copenhagen convention, that is the convention outlawing all forms of discrimination against women. I am told that that convention has been accepted by 78 countries. It is surprising to think that Australia is not amongst them.

Also, given the lack of enforcement provisions in the Bill, the Government could have given serious consideration to ratifying the optional protocol to the Covenant on Civil and Political Rights so that people could appeal to the International Human Rights Commission. I would suggest that it is precisely for the same reasons that the reservations were made to Article 50 of the Convention. That is because the Government is concerned that the international community should not find out that Australia's human rights record is not as rosy as it would like to portray it to be. Indeed, this Government speaks with a great deal of duplicity on human rights generally, both by its failure to do anything about human rights at State level in Australia, and because of the view it seems to take that human rights are devisible; something that we should urge for people in the Soviet Union-a view which we share-but that we should do nothing about human rights where our economic or strategic interests may be affected, a view which we reject totally. The uselessness of this Bill and the extraordinary width of Australia's reservations to the Covenant make Australia's position on international human rights much weaker than it should be.

Finally, I wish to refer to paragraph (g) of the Opposition's amendment. We remain concerned at the whittling away of the powers and the status of the Commissioner for Community Relations. The Commissioner will lose his power to report directly to Parliament, and he will lose a great deal of the resources which have made the office under Mr Grassby so successful for the last five years. Whilst the Government's amendment to the Racial Discrimination Act is technical, its defeat would mean that the 1979 Act would not come into operation, and we will oppose outright the Racial Discrimination Amendment Bill 1981. Over the years the Opposition has made its position clear. The Government is not concerned about human rights, either in Australia or elsewhere. Posturing at international forums is about as far as it ever gets. Knowing as we do that some Government back benchers would support our amendment if they were free to do so, we can simply urge the acceptance of our amendment, well knowing that it could be defeated and that this tame Commission will come into operation. As Australians, we all regret that this country has not been able to do a great deal better on human rights. Accordingly, I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: 'the Bill be withdrawn and re-drafted to provide for-
(a) its application to the laws and practices of the States and the Northern Territory;
(b) the full application, without the reservations and declarations embodied in Australia's ratification, of the rights contained in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights;
(c) the specific adoption in judicially enforceable form (along the lines of the Human Rights Bill 1973) of the rights contained in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights;

(d) the extension of the Commission's jurisdiction to enable it to investigate and report upon possible breaches of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (which includes guarantees of the rights to form and join trade unions, social security, and adequate standards of living, work, physical and mental health, education and to take part in cultural life);
(e) the extension of the Commission's jurisdiction to enable it to enforce the rights contained in the U.N. Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women;
(f) the expansion of the powers and functions of the Commission to give it a more effective enforcement role, especially in relation to civil and political rights, and

(g) in relation to racial discrimination matters, the retention of the independent status and functions, and especially the power to report directly to Parliament of the Commissioner for Community Relations.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment, Mr Deputy Speaker. Principle 10 of the Declaration of the Rights of the Child as proclaimed by the United Nations on 20 November 1959, which document it is proposed be incorporated in Australia's Human Rights Commission Bill, declares:

SPEECH.PARA: The child shall be protected from practices which may foster racial, religious and any other form of discrimination. He shall be brought up in a spirit of understanding, tolerance, friendship amongst peoples, peace and universal brotherhood, and in full consciousness that his energy and talents should be devoted to the service of his fellow men.

If the sentiments expressed in this passage were achieved, we would hear the sigh of relief rising across the world, because our major problems would be resolved. If they were achieved and applied, firstly, to the deliberations in this chamber and thence to those in every boardroom, union, factory, school, home and institution in Australia, social injustice would be resolved in this country and one would hear a shout of glee from our pensioners. We in this chamber would be voting in unison to lift the burden of the disadvantaged in our nation. Rather than there being opposition to the constructive amendments being put forward by the Opposition I hoped that there would be consideration of the facts put forward by Government members and that we would vote to pass these amendments.

It is a sobering thought that we in this chamber should have the task and responsibility of weighing up and choosing those basic rights which we believe every Australian citizen should possess. Having made this choice it is necessary to strengthen it with legislation as strong as that which strengthens the ideological direction 'thou shalt not kill'. But this is not the case with the legislation under review. That is one of the sound reasons why the Opposition is putting forward amendments to rectify the omission. I repeat that I hope that Government members who really believe in the basic rights of man, woman and child, will support these amendments.

To date this debate on human rights in this country has generated a lot of noise, a lot of hot air. I am concerned that this will be as far as the Government's commitment to ensuring real rights for humans in need of protection will go. The only noise created by the Human Rights Commission will be the gnashing of gums of a toothless paper tiger. Australia must not use this legislation merely to demonstrate its bona fide in the brotherhood of nations or its justification in claiming to be a soul brother to the black African nations. The Commission must not become a sop to the international pretensions of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), something for him to tuck under one arm as he strides the world stage of international affairs.

I do not necessarily subscribe to the edict that charity begins at home if home means one's own parish only. We are part of a global village and should accept a broad responsibility for the welfare of our fellow man. Surely the achievement of human rights should begin at home. How can we offer to cure the ills of other societies when we have shown that we cannot cure our own. We appear to have an ingrained parochial notion that human rights are those rights which other nations infringe. Nothing could be further from the truth. Australia, and particularly Queensland, is blazed with a trail of instances where people without status or power in our community are denied their fundamental rights. This legislation, as far as it goes, aims to rectify this undesirable situation in two ways: Firstly, by widening the terms of reference of the Human Rights Commission as provided in the Human Rights Commission Bill 1979 and, secondly, by extending the so-called jurisdiction of the Commission to possible infringements of those rights proclaimed through recent United Nations declarations-the declarations on the rights of the child, the rights of the mentally retarded and the rights of the disabled.

The wider application of the legislation serves to explain and highlight the wider implications of human rights as being more than a report in the overseas news section of the morning newspaper. Let us take as an example the implication regarding the rights of the unborn child. Recognition of prenatal injuries or accidents gives to the human who has been injured or affected by accident the right to sue. If Labor's amendments are adopted and the Commission is given power, inclusion of the rights of the child will enable the Federal Government to investigate through the Commission the operation of State laws relating to children and minors. There are aspects of Queensland's child welfare system which frankly are appalling. The rights of minors is an area of authority in which State governments have been traditionally unchallenged to the detriment of minors. In 1979, 4,000 minors came before the Children's Court in Queensland. Estimates suggest that seven or eight out of every ten were not legally represented.

Some provisions of the Children's Services Act in Queensland are brutal and archaic. I know of young girls aged 12, 13 or 14 in my electorate of Lilley who have been forced from the family home through brutalisation at home. Such girls are picked up by the police and institutionalised because they are in moral danger. They are housed with convicted felons. That is a shocking situation. The fact that it should be allowed to exist is an indictment of our society. Juvenile justice in Queensland ought to be high on the Commission's agenda for investigation. I place on record my support for the submission made by the Reverend Wally Dethless for the Brisbane Youth Advocacy Centre, the aims of which I would like to have incorporated in Hansard. This ties in with what I am talking about, and the Centre is meeting an existing need. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Unfortunately, if the Bill in question is left unamended, recording moral support for such a worthy initiative is just about the limit of a Federal member's power in this area. Even with the Human Rights Commission and the extension of its charter to include the rights of the child I fear that the Queensland Government's children's services legislation and the implementing authorities will remain untouchable. The United States Federal Government has begun withholding or withdrawing funds from the States where those funds are used to incarcerate young people. It has some power as the overriding authority which gives the money, and it requires certain standards. At the same time it is making more funds available for rehabilitative strategies and programs, which is a much better way of dealing with this situation. If this House passes amendments which give power to the Commission I hope this sort of action will eventuate from the work of the Commission. The Commission is useless without that power. This is the sort of action which I would like to see the Commission recommending to the Federal Government. Why should it not recommend such action? I am afraid that such action would be considered unthinkable by the Federal Government which is bound by the policies of federalism put forward by the Prime Minister and which appears to treat the Queensland Premier as an unchallengable, independent foreign head of state.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to those thinking members on the Government benches-I know that there are some of them-that the Commission can consider but it cannot act. Admittedly, it cannot act and it does not purport to do so. The Commission can consider breaches of rights beyond the traditional civil and political rights but its functions extend very little beyond consideration of human rights violations. In the 1979 legislation the Commission was conceived to ensure compliance with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights adopted by the United Nations in 1966 and signed by Australia on 18 December 1972. The signing of that Covenant was one of the first actions of the then Labor Government.

The establishment of the Commission was one of the obligations Australia accepted as a signatory. The range of rights encompassed by that Covenant includes the inherent rights to life-sadly that has become a slogan rather than a statement of principle-freedom from cruel and degrading treatment, freedom from arbitrary arrest and detention, freedom of thought, the presumption of innocence, the right to trial within a reasonable time, the liberty of movement, the freedoms of conscience, religion, expression and peaceful assembly. One additional covenant which should be considered for inclusion within the scope of the Commission is the 1966 International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights which was signed by Australia at the same time as the Covenant to which I referred previously.

Another obvious extension of the field of human rights would be the inclusion of the 1979 United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. Who on the Government benches is prepared to deny that women face disadvantages and discrimination in gaining access to housing, credit, employment, training, education and legal representation, and in the taxation and social security systems? It seems the height of hypocrisy and inconsistency to sign a declaration outlawing all forms of discrimination against women and then do absolutely nothing to enforce or back up that commitment. To call such an exercise window dressing is an understatement. It can be nothing more than base political expediency. I note with pleasure that Senator Susan Ryan will be moving to rectify the situation.

The Opposition has put the view that the legislation, by widening the areas of concern through the inclusion of some United Nations covenants not previously included in the 1979 legislation, is merely extending the Commission's inadequacy and inefficacy to new areas of human rights. Instead of being useless in two categories of human rights as already tabled, it will now be useless in four categories. That is this Government's version of progress. It is virtually pointless to extend the Commission's scope as this legislation would do, or to call, as the Opposition has done, for even greater extension if the Commission does not have the authority, the executive power and the statutory muscle to support its jurisdiction. This Commission is charged with monitoring, investigation and reporting on some but not all human rights violations.

One does not need glasses to see the holes in this legislation. The Bill's provisions are not judicially enforceable. As the Women's Electoral Lobby has observed, the Bill has so many exclusions to the obtaining of information by subpoena that it is almost impossible to make a case to put before a court. Alternatively, cases which are brought before a court can be dismissed on the basis that they would somehow be against the public interest. Defendants or witnesses in such cases can refuse to testify on the grounds of self-incrimination. The greatest inadequacy of the Commission is that its limited powers do not extend to the jurisdiction of State and Northern Territory governments. I speak as a Queenslander. In my maiden question in this Parliament, which was on human rights in Queensland, specifically the treatment of Aborigines in that State, which is shocking, I sought to draw the Prime Minister's attention to his greatest constitutional weapon in enforcing human rights observance on the States-the external affairs power. The Prime Minister rejected my suggestion. He stated:
In the view of this Government it--
That is, the foreign affairs power-
would be a wrong way to achieve a desirable objective.

Is the elimination of what I referred to in my question as 'the infringements of human rights and maltreatment of minorities in Queensland' not a desirable objective? I say that it is not only a desirable objective; two imminent events make it an immediate objective. If it is not achievable by the foreign affairs power, even greater attention should be given to the Australian Labor Party's amendments which are under discussion now. The events I refer to are the Commonwealth Games which are to be held in Brisbane and the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. The Prime Minister runs the risk of having the termites from Queensland undermining his international platforms. With the spotlight on Australia and on his own back yard, the Prime Minister may feel a little less self-righteous in championing the cause of human rights and may feel a little more disposed to using the only real and effective means he has at his disposal to achieve that desirable objective. Implicit in the Prime Minister's reply was the fact that the foreign affairs power does exist and could be used. The only question mark hangs over whether it should be used. We on this side have no hesitation in saying that it must be used.

As a Queenslander, I would note that the Premier of my State has the same attitude to the issue of civil and human rights as he does to income tax. He prefers to flatten it and, if he cannot do that, then avoid it. His Government's suppression of civil and political rights is already well documented. It is a catalogue of incredible political and personal abuse of human rights violations and infringements of civil liberties which has earned for the Queensland Government the odious distinction of being included in a list which was compiled by the United States Department of State of governments accused of such violations.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is still being elected.

—Australia is not or should not be half a dozen foreign countries. It should be one cohesive body. The Federal Government, if it is to justify its existence, must accept some responsibility for its people in every State. Regrettably, in answer to the honourable member for Franklin, the Queensland Government is still being elected. Really that is the reason we need to give power to this legislation-to keep that Government under control.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, I put it to you that honourable members on the other side of the chamber should demonstrate their concern for the insufficiency in the Human Rights Commission Bill by supporting the amendment moved by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harris Mr G.McD.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address myself to two aspects of the Human Rights Commission Bill. The purpose of this Bill is to establish, as we all know, a Human Rights Commission. This Commission would promote the observance of human rights throughout Australia and immediately within the limits of Commonwealth law. It is contemplated, I hope, that in co-operation with the States regarding human rights matters, the Commission will assist the Government in carrying out Australia's international responsibilities in the cause of human rights. This obligation was undertaken by Australia as a party to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. I am glad that the Bill seems likely, finally, to pass in to law. It has had a difficult and much delayed course in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, there are two matters which I wish to discuss. The first is that the Commission will, at least initially, be limited in its operation to the laws of the Commonwealth and its Territories. It is true that clause 11 of the Bill provides for arrangements to be made between the Federal Government, and the State governments and the Government of the Northern Territory. Pursuant to that clause the Attorney-General may make arrangements for the performance on a joint basis of functions relating to the promotion of the observance of human rights in a State or a Territory. He may arrange for the performance by a State or a Territory or by an authority of a State or Territory on behalf of the Commonwealth of functions relating to the promotion of the observance of human rights. That includes the functions of the Human Rights Commission itself. Further, that clause permits, by agreement, the performance by the Commission of functions on behalf of a State or a Territory relating to the promotion of the observance of human rights. There can be no argument that the kind of arrangements proposed in clause 11 would enable the laws of a State or a Territory to be subject to the provisions of the Bill and the attentions of the Human Rights Commission.

The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has said that clause 11 provides for a range of co-operative arrangements to be entered into with the States and that it is his expectation that this mechanism will be fully used. I certainly hope so. On a previous occasion when I spoke in this place I argued, in a different area of law, for a reference of State powers to the Commonwealth. I would not like it to be thought that I am seeking a wholesale takeover of State responsibilities by the Commonwealth. That is simply not so. On the prior occasion I was simply talking about the area of family law, which in my view ought to come under one law covering the whole Commonwealth. Here I concede and readily accept that what we are talking about in regard to State laws is a whole variety of laws which, in my view, quite rightly, are the domain of the States. In many of those areas they affect human rights. Clearly the kinds of things which we are contemplating in this Human Rights Bill ought to apply to State law as they will do to Federal law.

I would greatly prefer that the arrangements proposed in clause 11 be used and work successfully. I would much prefer that we work as a federal body and not intrude into areas which the States ought to be managing. It must be acknowledged, as has been mentioned earlier in this debate, that in some areas of State activity the human rights record is scarcely one which is commendable. The record of the States, put at its gentlest, can be described as an uneven one. I hope the States realise that if they wish federalism to work, as I am sure all of us on our side of the House, and I hope all of us do, they must play their part. Where opportunities are there for co-operation they ought to co-operate.

The provisions in clause 11 do not in any way impugn State sovereignty. If the States co-operate pursuant to that provision they will have their own means of ensuring that their laws comply with the Human Rights Commission Bill. The Attorney has said that ministerial meetings on human rights will continue to exercise a role at a top policy level in considering these issues. He believes continuing consultation between the various levels of government will promote generally the cause of human rights in Australia. As I have said, I hope that he is right. I urge him to take every opportunity to encourage the use of the procedures provided in the Bill. As I have said, I hope that the State governments appreciate that if they do not contribute as they ought one day one government in the federal sphere may seek to intrude where the States would not wish it to.

The other matter I wish to raise relates to the inclusion in the schedules to the present Bill of three Declarations. Schedules 2, 3 and 4 contain the Declaration of the Rights of the Child, 1959; the Declaration on the Rights of the Mentally Retarded, 1971; and the Declaration on the Rights of the Disabled, 1975. When a similar Bill was last before the Parliament its passage was stalled because of the differences of view concerning what was described as the Simon amendment. The Bill in its present form has been defused very largely by including the Declaration of the Rights of the Child in Schedule 2. The third paragraph in the preamble to the Declaration recites:
. . . the child, by reason of his physical and mental immaturity, needs special safeguards and care, including appropriate legal protection, before as well as after birth . . .

The Declaration of the Rights of the Child calls for men and women everywhere, in voluntary organisations and in governments, to strive for the observance of the rights of the child which it proclaims. Each of the three declarations does not involve the same kind of commitment in international law as does the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. It is intended that the Human Rights Commission will monitor and report on the way in which the Commonwealth departments and agencies conform to them. It can be only for the best that the different views expressed in the previous debate have now been able to be resolved with the inclusion of these three declarations. This is not the kind of measure that we would wish to have passed in an atmosphere of bitterness, as I think the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) described the prior debate. To succeed, the Commission needs to have the widest possible support throughout the community.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has moved an amendment which commences with the request that the Bill be withdrawn and redrafted to provide for various measures. I do not wish to discuss the substance of those proposed matters for redrafting. It seems to me that if we do that we will be back where we started and the Bill may never be successfully passed. To withdraw and redraft now would impose further delay. Whenever the Bill next comes before the Parliament-of course, it would have to go back through the two Houses-would be the opportunity to reopen matters which have previously been debated. We cannot be sure what the course of this legislation would then be. The amendment indeed is not an amendment to the Bill itself. It is an amendment to the motion that the Bill be now read a second time. As I understand it, if the amendment were carried the Bill would certainly not be proceeded with today. In fact, one assumes that it would never proceed. That I think would be the worst possible result. I hope that the Bill can now be passed with the general agreement of all, notwithstanding reservations people may have about various facets of it. I hope that the Commission can be brought into operation as soon as possible. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In joining in the debate on the Human Rights Commission Bill I take the opportunity of declaring my disappointment at certain aspects of the Bill which, I believe, indicate considerable deficiencies in the proposed operation of the Human Rights Commission. Australia has been long overdue for a Bill of Rights, but the present Bill is a rather pale imitation of the kind of safeguards of civil liberties which many Australians have been demanding for years. It is questionable whether the proposed Human Rights Commission is better than nothing at all. One thing is certain, however, and that is that there are serious omissions which I would now like to draw to the attention of honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: In referring to the provisions of the Bill I will not be using the precise language of the Bill. I believe honourable members will not find any difficulty in following the points I wish to make. I turn to sub-clause (4) of clause 10 which gives the Commission the power to decide not to hold an inquiry as a result of a complaint if, amongst other things:
(a) the complaint is frivolous or vexatious or is not made in good faith;
(b) the subject-matter of the complaint is trivial;

Note the words 'frivolous', 'vexatious' and 'trivial' and the phrase 'not made in good faith'. These terms are highly subjective. In effect, they mean that the Commission could decide not to hold an inquiry for a variety of political reasons. How many street marchers and demonstrators have been described by our national newspapers as frivolous and vexatious people?

TALK.START.PARA: —Hundreds in Queensland.

—That is right. Is it likely that the Commission would consider a complaint of a violation of human rights from such a person as worthy of an inquiry? Likewise the word 'frivolous' can be applied quite differently depending upon the political or philosophical view of a commissioner. At the very least there should be a right of appeal against a decision of the Commission not to hold an inquiry on the grounds contained in paragraphs (a) and (b) of sub-clause (4) of clause 10. Again, in sub-clause (5) of clause 10 the Commission has the power not to hold an inquiry if 12 months has elapsed since the act complained of occurred. This time limit appears unreasonably restrictive. One could envisage many possible cases of a violation of human rights when it may take a considerable time before sufficient evidence could be accumulated which would convince the commissioners that the complaint was genuine. The time limit should be extended to at least two years. There should also be a right of appeal against the decision of the commissioners.

SPEECH.PARA: Another provision of the Bill which contains considerable deficiencies is sub-clause (2) of clause 15 by which it is possible to prevent the disclosure of evidence relevant to a human rights violation by certification from the Attorney-General that this disclosure would be contrary to the public interest. Here we have another of these vague, indeterminate terms-'contrary to the public interest'. What is the public interest? Let us take the example of the Vietnam war. The then Liberal Party-led Federal Government considered that any protest against the war was contrary to the public interest. Had this Bill been in operation at that time, any person whose human rights had been violated because of his protest against such a war would have been unable to obtain evidence to support his complaint. Yet we all know that Australia's participation in the Vietnam war was a crime against the Vietnamese people. What is contrary to the public interest is a subjective judgment which depends upon the political complexion of the government in power at the time of the alleged human rights violation. The invoking of sub-clause (2) could mean that a multitude of human rights violations could not be proceeded against because the complainant was unable to obtain essential information.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be worse than in Russia, wouldn't it?

—The honourable member is right; it would be worse. It is true that it is not the Attorney-General but the Chairman of the Commission who is to decide whether the disclosure of the information would be contrary to the public interest, but does anyone believe that the Chairman would oppose the view of the Attorney-General? The precedents provided by the actions of the chairmen of other such statutory bodies do not give me any confidence that the Chairman of this Commission would take an independent view on such a matter. In its practical effect, the provisions of clause 15 (2) would make the gathering of information almost impossible-in circumstances in which human rights violations could be legion. Another serious flaw in clause 15 is contained in sub-clause (8), which declares:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that it is a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse to furnish information or produce a document . . . or to refuse to answer a question . . . when giving evidence under this section that the information, the production of the document or the answer to the question might tend to incriminate him.

That is, I might add, a sexist phrase. I would have hoped that our legislators might have come to terms with that matter. Why is a guilty party given such an option? The violation of human rights is a serious matter and no guilty person should be permitted to take this easy way of evading his or her responsibility. Surely it would have been possible to include a sub-clause which would have effectively ensured that the incriminating evidence would not be used against such a person. When the effect of this sub-clause is added to that of sub-clause (2), and so many potential violators can use those escape clauses to avoid the publication of their activities, one wonders whether the Government is really serious in its avowed intention of promoting the observance of human rights.

Another grave deficiency is the lack of publicity which will be given by the Commission to human rights violations. Clause 16 specifies that where, after inquiry, the Commission finds that an act or practice is inconsistent with or contrary to any human rights, it shall report to the appropriate Minister accordingly. Publicity is not required and no sanctions are specified, so non-government offenders could completely ignore the findings. It is true that in due course, the Minister would table the report in Parliament, but the progress of a report through the parliamentary procedures can be long and tedious. It would not be difficult to conceive an item's being delayed or even perhaps overlooked. My point is that the Commission should have the power to make public in a far more effective way, perhaps by official Press release, any transgression of human rights. These public announcements could be made immediately the Commission had concluded its inquiry and need not be subject to the delay and undue formality that are associated with publishing a report.

I consider that another important deficiency in the Bill is that there is no right of appeal against the findings of the commissioners which arise from their inquiry. I believe that the adoption of a Bill on human rights in Australia has been long overdue, but it gives me cause for great regret that the Government has abdicated its responsibilities by producing such a weak and ineffective body as the proposed Human Rights Commission. Of course, I accept that in practical terms there can be no such thing as a value-free or neutral interpretation of human rights. Frequently, debates on human rights in Australia ignore the economic, cultural and social processes which result in millions of Australian workers and their families suffering unemployment, poverty and cultural deprivation. Such people suffer the deprivation of their human rights just as surely as if they were physically restrained or maltreated. In particular, the human rights of the Aboriginal people of Australia are being violated every day, in the States of Western Australia and Queensland especially.

Another aspect of human rights which is often neglected is the right of workers in their work place. At present few employers are willing to grant their employees the right to participate in the decision-making processes in relation to their work, yet in many countries this elementary human right is well recognised and is operating as a part of normal industrial relations.

As I have mentioned these few matters it must be clear to honourable members that I am less than enthusiastic about the provisions of the Bill. I realise that they have been before the House on a previous occasion. I can only express my disappointment that the Government, in resubmitting the Bill, has not seen fit to remedy the serious deficiencies that I have outlined. I support the amendment that has been moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Human Rights Commission Bill is a very significant piece of legislation. As is well known to honourable members, it has been before the House on a previous occasion. In my submission, it cannot be denied that the present Bill is a far more desirable piece of legislation than that which was previously before us. That is so for a number of reasons, one of which is that it now includes in its schedules a covenant, the full title of which is the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and three very significant declarations. The first, which is contained in Schedule 2, is the Declaration of the Rights of the Child, one of whose preambles includes the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: Whereas the child, by reason of his physical and mental immaturity, needs special safeguards and care, including appropriate legal protection, before as well as after birth.

It is appropriate that the House should have before it a piece of legislation which recognises that fact and recognises it as a proposition which is contained in the Declaration of the Rights of the Child. Too often, I suspect, we overlook in legislation the rights of those who, for whatever reason, cannot speak for themselves. The paragraph which I have read refers to one such reason. We are concerned with children before as well as after they are born. I support the manner in which the Government has approached this issue-by including in a schedule the Declaration of the Rights of the Child, to which the Human Rights Commision of course will have regard in its deliberations. So it is appropriate in every respect that we have on the record now, as one of the matters to which the Human Rights Commission will have regard, recognition of the fact that one important group of people to whom attention should be given when we are considering human rights is unborn children. I compliment the Government upon approaching the issue in this manner.

The Bill establishes a Human Rights Commission. One of its functions, as set out in clause 9 (1) (f), is 'to promote an understanding and acceptance, and the public discussion, of human rights in Australia and the external Territories'. I presume that means, amongst other things, that the Commission will encourage discussion in Australia of issues of human rights. It is on one of those subjects that I wish to address some remarks to the House tonight.

Debate on the Bill is, in general terms, important for a number of reasons. The first is that it provides an opportunity to express our concern for human rights and their preservation; secondly, it enables us to consider the human rights issues involved when we set up machinery to examine breaches of human rights, as we are doing now by means of this Bill; and, thirdly, the legislation reminds us, because of the international treaties that in effect we are implementing by means of this legislation, that human rights is an international issue. I have already drawn the attention of the House to the fact that one of the functions of the Commission is to promote an understanding and acceptance, and the public discussion, of human rights in Australia and the external Territories. It is in that area that I wish to make some remarks. The basis of those remarks is a motion of which notice was given by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) on 4 December 1980. That motion relates to the denial of human rights of the Baha'i people in Iran. The motion of which the honourable member for Mackellar gave notice reads:
That this House-

(1) expresses its grave concern over the persecution of the 200,000 adherents of the Baha'i faith in Iran by the regime of the Ayatollah Khomeini, and notes with alarm the recent execution of a member of the Baha'i faith in Tabriz solely on the grounds of his religion;

(2) calls upon the Government of Iran to release from custody those Baha'is, including 9 members of the National Spiritual Assembly of Baha'is of Iran, who have been unjustly detained, and to restore the holy places, properties, community centres and companies that have been confiscated;
(3) commends the Australian Government for its assistance to Australian Baha'is in expressing their protest to the Iranian Government, and

(4) requests the Australian Government to lend its support to moves in international forums designed to restore to the Iranian Baha'is their freedom to live their lives in peace and practice their religion in harmony with their fellow citizens of other faiths.

The honourable member for Mackellar also spoke on that issue in the adjournment debate on an earlier occasion. I give him credit for raising the issue by that means. Part of the motion commends the Australian Government for its assistance to Australian Baha'is in expressing their protest to the Iranian Government against this particular and fundamental denial of human rights. It is therefore appropriate to consider this issue further in the debate on this legislation. It is also appropriate to do so because, as I have already said, one of the functions of the Commission will be to promote an understanding and acceptance, and the public discussion, of human rights in Australia and the external Territories.

The substance of the matter can be compressed into a number of short points. I hope that I can put them on the record in a few moments. The situation is that, in the first place, the 300,000 to 400,000 members of the Baha'i religion in Iran have been harassed in the exercise of their religion; secondly, their centres have been raided and documents, including their membership lists, have been seized; thirdly, their spiritual meetings and religious classes have been broken up and their teachers have been arrested; and, fourthly, their trading company has been confiscated and its employees interrogated. Their buildings and land which have been used solely for religious purposes have been taken over by the Government and their national headquarters, cemeteries and hospital have been confiscated. Fifthly, some of the members have been dismissed from government service in Iran because of religious beliefs and for no other reason whatsoever; and, sixthly, one of the Ayatollahs has said that Baha'is are people whom Moslems may annihilate without fear of punishment. They have been branded as apostates and abused, and their religion has been denied as a legitimate religion. Seventhly-this is far worse than all that-they have been persecuted and beaten and their leaders have been arrested. Indeed, some adherents of this faith have been executed.

These are violations of the most fundamental human rights that we could possibly articulate. They deserve to be condemned in the strongest terms. In particular, they are violations of Article 18 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which was signed by Iran, amongst other countries. These violations are also contrary to Article 27 of the Covenant, which is set out in a schedule to the very Bill that we are debating tonight. Article 27 reads as follows:

In those States in which ethnic, religious or linguistic minorities exist, persons belonging to such minorities shall not be denied the right, in community with the other members of their group, to enjoy their own culture, to profess and practise their own religion, or to use their own language.
The first two paragraphs of Article 18 state:

1. Everyone shall have the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion. This right shall include freedom to have or to adopt a religion or belief of his choice, and freedom, either individually or in community with others and in public or private to manifest his religion or belief in worship, observance, practice and teaching.
2. No one shall be subject to coercion which would impair his freedom to have or to adopt a religion or belief of his choice.

It is appropriate that we should have it very firmly in our minds that the Covenant contains those declarations of very basic human rights. I hope that when the Commission is established it has regard to those rights and to breaches which occur, even if they occur outside Australia; so long as that can help to illustrate in accordance with the Commission's functions the fact that basic human rights exist, that on occasions those human rights are broken and that when they are broken those breaches should be condemned. We can conclude from all of this that, first of all, the adherents of the Baha'i faith are being persecuted in breach of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which is annexed to this Bill, and in breach of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. We can conclude secondly that their religion and its survival in Iran are at risk.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I thank you for your indulgence in enabling me to make those points which may not, on immediate consideration, be relevant to the precise clauses of the legislation but I know that the views I have expressed are the views also of many, if not all, members of the Opposition in this Parliament who would, like honourable members on this side of the Parliament, wish to record their condemnation of the denial of basic human rights. Without taking up more of the time of the House, I wish to incorporate in Hansard-I think permission has been given in advance by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen)-some declarations which are similar to the views I have expressed. That will avoid the necessity of my speaking longer. Nevertheless it will put on the record the views of both this Parliament and a number of international bodies about these very grievous breaches of human rights to which I have been referring. The first document is a resolution of the European Parliament passed on 19 September 1980. The second is a written declaration, being No. 88 of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe, dated 29 September 1980. The third is a motion passed by the House of Commons of Canada on 16 July 1980. The fourth is a declaration on the state of religious minorities in Iran made by the Federation of Protestant Churches in Switzerland, Human Rights Commission, on 12 September 1979. I ask leave to incorporate those documents in Hansard.
Leave granted.

recalling its unfailing attachment to the international protection of human rights,

concerned at the systematic campaign of persecution directed in Iran against the 300,000 members of the Bahai community (the biggest religious minority in Iran) and the accompanying violations of fundamental human rights, in particular:

(b) the summary arrest, detention and execution of leaders of the Bahai community,

Condemnation of Persecution of Religious Minorities in Iran-Motion under S.O. 43

Mr Geoff Scott (Hamilton-Wentworth): Madam Speaker, I rise, under the provisions of Standing Order 43, on a grave matter of urgency which I hope will receive a sympathetic support on all sides of this House.

In view of at least 26 more Iranians dying on Monday before a firing squad, including two leaders of the Baha'i religious sect, I move, seconded by the honourable member for Eglinton-Lawrence (Mr de Corneille):

That this House of Commons deplores the continued persecution of religious minorities in Iran, especially the 200,000 Baha'is, and urges that this total abuse of religious tolerance be brought to the attention of the Human Rights Committee of the United Nations.
Madam Speaker: Such a motion requires the unanimous consent of the House. Is there unanimous consent?
Some hon. Members: Agreed.
Madam Speaker: Is it the pleasure of the House to adopt the motion?
Some hon. Members: Agreed.

DECLARATION ON THE STATE OF RELIGIOUS MINORITIES IN IRAN
In agreement with the executive committee of the federation of protestant Churches in Switzerland, its human rights commission publishes the enclosed document on the state of the Baha'is in Iran.
At the beginning of July all federal parliamentarian groups appealed to the Iranian authorities to grant freedom of conscience (in german it means religious freedom K.S.) to the Baha'is in Iran.

At the same time, the human rights commission of the federation of protestant Churches in Switzerland received this documentation on the situation of the Baha'is in Iran, with the request to publish it once notified.

End of August we were notified to proceed. Meanwhile the Iranian government has taken further actions against the Baha'is. Thus, at the registration, children who declare their membership in this religious community are not admitted to school. Further, 37 national Baha'i leaders have been put on the list of those who may not leave Iran. At present their sanctuaries which are of international importance, are profaned and destroyed.

The 300,000 Christians, who mostly belong to ethnical minorities are, it seems, subjected to less important oppressions. Nevertheless their hospitals have been confiscated, correspondence courses had to be stopped and libraries were closed. The Iranian members of the episcopal-Church have been affected most.

We are aware that here it is not only a question of the rights of Baha'is or Christians, but of the religious freedom of minorities and the respect of the dignity of all the peoples living in Iran in general. Terrified by the persecution of the Kurds, we are publishing this document today in the hope that those personalities invested with the task of elaboration a new constitution for Iran would pay special attention to the protection of minorities and would grant religious freedom.
