TALK.START.PARA: —Finally, may I thank the Deputy Leader of the Opposition for his concurrence in the incorporation and express the hope that all members of the House believe, as I do, that breaches of human rights, no matter where they occur, should be roundly condemned; that the particular breaches to which I have referred are very serious and fundamental breaches of very basic human rights and that they should be condemned by all civilised countries and all civilised peoples.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Human Rights Commission Bill 1981 now before this House contains essentially the same unsatisfactory elements as the original 1979 Bill. The major objections now are as they were then and I will just outline them briefly. They are, firstly, the failure of the Bill to apply to the States; secondly, the failure to create judicially enforceable rights of any kind; thirdly, the failure to give the proposed Human Rights Commission any effective power; and fourthly, the absorption of the Office of the Commissioner for Community Relations into this Commission, thus downgrading the status and independence of the Office of Community Relations. The Opposition has proposed amendments to rectify these deficiencies in the legislation. I hope that the Government will give these very serious consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: A further aspect of the 1981 Bill also deserves some attention. In extending the provisions of the Bill in relation to children, the mentally retarded and the disabled, we are moving into an area of social, economic and cultural rights. These are indisputably human rights too, but they require the provision of services and resources to achieve their ends, rather than merely judicial decisions and judgments as in the case of civil and political rights. It would be preferable to include all the areas under the umbrella of social, economic and cultural rights rather than just these three examples and consider giving the Commission jurisdiction to enable it to investigate and report on possible breaches of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, as outlined in the Opposition's amendment.

There are several glaring omissions in this respect are provisions for Aboriginals, migrants and women, as well as many others. In particular the Bill does not extend the jurisdiction of the Human Rights Commission to the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women signed by Australia in July 1980. There should be no need for me to explain the great improvements that are needed for improving the status of women in this country. All we have to do is look around this House to see a glaring example of the inequalities of women in our society. We have only three female members in this House, all from the Opposition, and there have only ever been six women members of the House of Representatives. That is appalling discrimination. But more importantly, women in Australia continue to be discriminated against in terms of educational and employment opportunities. Eight years after an Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission decision giving equal pay for men and women, there is still an average 48 per cent gap in pay rates. Average weekly earnings for women are $142 compared with $227 for men.

Of course it is not only in terms of remuneration that women in the work force suffer discrimination. Women have traditionally been confined by their training and by their social expectations, to the lower status, lower-paid sales, clerical, factory and service occupations. An Australian Council of Trade Union working women's survey which was recently undertaken illustrated that even in the most traditional female occupation, that is housekeeping, women were paid an average of $173.80 compared with male housekeepers, who received an average of $286.30. As well as menial, low-paid work, sexual harassment and poor conditions further disadvantaged the female work force. When we examine the professional, higher-paid, higher status occupations we find them largely monopolised by men. Many studies have shown that it is not enough for a woman to be equal in competence to men, but that the woman has to be markedly superior in competence to do a particular job in order to overcome the negative and entrenched social attitudes which cause so much of the discrimination suffered by women.

These same negative attitudes contribute to enormous discrimination against women in many other areas as well as the work force. In access to housing, credit, financial services and legal services women must battle strongly to be treated as persons and to be treated with dignity and respect. Australia has paid lip service to the concept of human rights for some considerable time and has not sought actively to promote the rights of women. Although some States have recently introduced encouraging anti-discrimination legislation, I note that the Federal Government has still failed to introduce such legislation, its own employees and residents of the Australian Capital Territory have no protection under anti-discrimination legislation.
In relation to rights for women and other disadvantaged groups, Australia has committed itself to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Article 2 of this Declaration states:

Everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth in this Declaration, without distinction of any kind, such as race, colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status.
We might also look at Article 7, which states:
All are equal before the law and are entitled without any discrimination to equal protection of the law.

We compare these words with the realities facing women in Australia who need legal assistance or protection. For example, we might consider the plight of those who cannot meet the means test requirement for legal aid, or the plight of women in refuges, or the plight of those affected by inequitable family law property settlements.

Australia has also ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which extends the provisions of the Universal Declaration, and we have signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, although this has not yet been ratified. It is time that this rhetoric was translated into action. The Federal Government should take the lead in this matter and not just leave it to the States. We need a uniform, coherent policy and commitment to the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women.

The Federal Government has constitutional powers on its side as well as a strong moral obligation to provide effective legislation in these matters. The Commonwealth, as the largest employer in this country, could set a standard for all employers in ensuring that equality of opportunity exists for women in the Public Service. The current situation, as outlined in the 1980 Statistical Year Book of the Public Service Board, points out some of the discrimination in this area. There are no female First Division officers and only 27 out of 1,319 Second Division officers are females. This is totally unacceptable. This inequitable situation clearly indicates that the Federal Government should put its own house in order if it wishes to claim that it supports the various human rights conventions outlined earlier.

My colleague, Senator Ryan, in another place has drawn attention to the powers of the Commonwealth Government to outlaw discrimination in finance and banking. These are indeed crucial areas as many women have experienced the humiliating and degrading form of discrimination practised by lending institutions and have had to give up their attempts to provide a home for themselves and their families. The Bill before this House does not provide effective legislation for the establishment and promotion of human rights in Australia. It is poorly conceived and lacks any real power to achieve reform. The Women's Electoral Lobby, a group well known over the past 10 years for its work in promoting improvements in the status of women, has expressed strong reservations about this Bill and has argued for its rejection. I will quote from its recent statements on this matter. It states:

The Bill as drafted confers no further rights on women, Aborigines, other disadvantaged groups, or anyone at all. A commission set up under the proposed legislation would be ineffective, inconsequential and would have no teeth.
The Bill has so many exclusions that to the obtaining of information by subpoena that it is almost impossible to make a case . . .

There are no real sanctions in the Bill-the commissioner can write a letter to the culprit or take a report in some future parliamentary session. The Bill does not provide the right of appeal to the judiciary.
The inescapable conclusion of all this is, as WEL says:
The Bill is window dressing by the Australian Government to fool other nations into believing that Australia is carrying out its obligations under the United Nations Convention on Human Rights.

The issue of human rights is of great significance to us all as members of Australian society and deserved to be treated seriously and conscientiously, instead of in this cavalier fashion. I would urge all honourable members to consider the amendment moved by the Opposition and consult their conscience carefully before casting their vote on this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I first of all thank my colleague the honourable member for Diamond Valley (Mr N. A. Brown) for his kind support for my efforts to draw the attention of the House and the Australian people to the plight of the Baha'i community in Iran. I draw the attention of honourable members to my notice of motion No. 25 under General Business and hope that other honourable members will approach the Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) to see whether this matter can be brought before this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I would like to address my remarks to the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) to the Human Rights Commission Bill. The amendment contains a number of parts. The main objections put forward by the Opposition, which are reflected in this amendment, are that the Bill relates only to the Commonwealth jurisdiction and does not seek to override State legislation by using the power of foreign affairs under the Constitution. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has made quite clear why the Commonwealth does not wish to use that power. I regard this power as a somewhat artificial device. I believe it leads to a continuing warfare with the State governments which is very unproductive, and we had examples of this under the Labor Government. It kids people that the job of convincing citizens within each of the States to change attitudes over a period can somehow be neglected and that certain results can be obtained in a very fast fashion merely by passing legislation in this Federal Parliament.

The honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) in her speech used the words 'negative and entrenched social attitudes'. I would certainly endorse her remarks in relation to a number of situations in the Australian community. I would urge all members of the House, particularly members of the Opposition, if they are gravely dissatisfied with the way certain rights are not protected, as they believe, in certain States, to go about convincing the large number of citizens of those States that negative and entrenched social attitudes of the kind of which they disapprove, and of which I think we would all disapprove, ought to be dealt with by working to alter the policies of the governments which have the constitutional responsibility for those matters within those areas. I would certainly support that kind of activity and I believe that is the place for it to be done. If there is not any change in the hearts and minds of the people living in various parts of this Commonwealth, we can pass legislation here until we are black in the face; we can cause enormous disruption between federal and State governments as was done under the Whitlam Government. However, this would be totally counterproductive and would lead to a hardening of those attitudes. Therefore I think it is important to give the kind of lead we are giving in this legislation by setting up the Human Rights Commission and to raise these kinds of issues in a way which will lead progressively to real reform and real changes in those attitudes. In other words, it will be done by coaxing, by illustration, by example, by probing, by public debate, by gradually changing people's minds and not by entering into some kind of war with the States. Therefore I believe paragraph (a) of the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition regarding the application of these laws to the States and the Northern Territory is ill-advised.

The second paragraph of the amendment relates to full application, without the reservations and declarations embodied in Australia's ratification of the rights contained in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. This mainly relates to the same issue in that Australia's ratification of that covenant excluded its application to the States, unless the State governments themselves wished to enact their own legislation. Of course, these matters are taken up in the ministerial committee. So that part of the amendment is really much the same as the first part. Paragraph (c) of the amendment relates to the specific adoption in judicially enforceable form, along the lines of the Human Rights Bill 1973, of the rights contained in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. This relates to judicially enforceable powers given to the Commission. I think the Government's view is a sensible one since we are grafting on to a basically English system of civil rights which we already possess. When one looks at the position around the world one realises that Australia's commitment to the United Nations Convention on Human Rights is much more effective than the commitment in most other countries. We are drafting a new instrument on to a system of human rights which has been developed over some hundreds of years and which is generally very effective. Before determining whether any additional judicial enforcement is needed, we would like firstly to see which nooks and crannies require improvement before we bring in sweeping enforceable legislation across the whole range of issues, most of which are already the subject of laws which are enforceable by the courts in the existing system. So at this stage I think it would be unwise to proceed as far as that.

The fourth paragraph of the amendment relates to the extension of the Commission's jurisdiction to enable it to investigate and report upon possible breaches of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, which includes guarantees of the right to form and join trade unions; to enjoy social security, adequate standards of living, work, physical and mental health, and education; and to take part in cultural life. Enormous groups of laws, federal and State, cover all those things. We have been enacting laws in the Commonwealth Parliament since 1901 to cover all these things. The State parliaments have done so before that. To bring in an overriding set of further legislation in all those areas seems to me to be absolutely superfluous.

Paragraph (e) of the amendment relates to the extension of the Commission's jurisdiction to enable it to enforce the rights contained in the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. Whilst I think one might examine this matter more closely I think the remarks made by the honourable member for Canberra about negative and entrenched attitudes, particularly towards women, have a great deal of validity. I think there is an advance within this Bill because Article 3 of Schedule 1 states:
The States Parties to the present Covenant undertake to ensure the equal right of men and women to the enjoyment of all civil and political rights set forth in the present Covenant.

Since the Commission as established under this legislation would be required to take that into account with respect to federal legislation it is open to people to ask this Commission to take up those very issues under Commonwealth legislation. For instance, the employment of women by the Commonwealth could be taken up under the Public Service Act. It is up to people to get the Commission to look into those areas and to report to this Parliament on any cases where it believes there should be alterations to the legislation to protect the equal rights of women in the Commonwealth work force. Whilst conceding that in that area a great deal more needs to be done, I believe that contrary to what the honourable member for Canberra has said, there is a specific advance within this legislation enabling women and the Women's Electoral Lobby, in particular, who have drawn objection to it, to be very active within this area, I think to the advantage of women.

I have already covered paragraph (f) of the amendment relating to the expansion of the powers and functions of the Commission to give it a more effective enforcement role, especially in relation to civil and political rights. Finally, paragraph (g) of the amendment relates to racial discrimination matters and the retention of the independent status and functions, especially the power to report directly to Parliament, of the Commissioner for Community Relations. I think an historical reason exists as to why Opposition members are sensitive on this matter, their having appointed a former Labor Cabinet Minister to that position. The fact that he is in that position has no interest for me in relation to this legislation. It is perfectly sensible to combine that area of activity within the concept of this Bill.

In the few remaining minutes left for me to speak I refer to the holier than thou attitude which is adopted by members of the Opposition on legislation of this kind. Anyone would think that Opposition members are paragons of virtue in relation to human rights. Listening to them, one would think that this country is somehow gravely deficient in its responsibilities under the United Nations Convention on Human Rights. That is clearly not so. Australia is one of the outstanding countries in the world, with a developed system of human rights under its legal systems, State and Federal, which provides an extraordinary measure of freedom to the citizen. That does not mean that the system cannot be improved. This relatively modest measure seeks to improve the system in a way which will not damage it but will leave it open for further changes to be made in the future, should they be necessary.

I want to make some remarks about an area of threat to human rights which is totally overlooked by the Opposition. Grave threats to human rights are embodied in the federal platform of the Opposition party. I refer to threats to human rights within the area of industrial relations. No aspect of the life of the Australian community presents a more striking contrast between what the average person regards as fair and reasonable and what actually happens in practice than does the field of industrial relations. Denial of fundamental human freedoms such as freedom of association, practices designed to restrict trade thus reducing choice, and increasing costs and coercion of individuals without legal redress are all commonplace in the area of industrial relations. The ordinary citizen finds it hard to accept that such unjust practices can apparently be allowed to continue without the intrusion of the law when he himself is without doubt subject to the law. Equally, he cannot understand why parliaments, particularly the Federal Parliament, cannot pass legislation and enforce it to prevent these injustices, which occur every day and are reported in the media. They are well known--

TALK.START.PARA: —That makes it right, does it? That makes it accurate?

—The comments from the honourable member for Melbourne Ports attract my attention. I am not suggesting that because incidents are reported in the media they are right. I am suggesting that they are drawn to the attention of the public by the media and that those practices are clearly wrong. It is not only through the media that they become known. They become known through the common experience of people every day. An essential guarantee of freedom for the individual is that all people should be equal under the law. In successive generations a number of powerful groups seeking to exert unreasonable pressures on individual freedom have been circumscribed by legislation passed by parliaments and enforced through the courts. For example, in the course of the twentieth century, the powers of corporations have been subject to a wide range of legislation in such areas as companies and securities, trade practices, wages and conditions, industrial safety and environmental protection. All this legislation has been enforceable in the courts. The legislative restrictions on corporations were reinforced by the emergence of the trade union movement and established as a further countervailing force to the power of corporations and individual employers before the turn of the century and subsequently. It was and still is necessary for workers in some enterprises or industries to come together in trade unions or other forms of association to bargain with employers on an equal basis in order to secure what they regard to be fair returns for their work. Their right to do this is recognised and supported. A complete framework of legislation has been developed in Australia in order to ensure this right.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent years trade unions have increased their power relative to other groups in the community. Many trade unions have used this power in ways that individuals and corporations are prevented by law from using. In addition, particularly since 1969, some of them-only a few, but enough to make it very inconvenient for people-have felt free to defy industrial laws under the Federal Conciliation and Arbitration Act and similar State Acts, leading to serious industrial disruption and a serious denial of human rights for workers and consumers. Beyond the use of growing bargaining power within the area of industrial law, unions have also disputed the applicability of the general body of law to their actions. They become virtually exempt from the application of civil actions for damages arising out of disputes, using the threat of further industrial retaliation to prevent action being taken against them. They have also declared that they will resist the application of laws designed to prevent restrictive trade practices, although those laws already apply to corporations.

I merely point out that whilst we are being lectured by the Opposition, day in and day out, on our alleged lack of concern about human rights, the Opposition, by its very party platform-any honourable member can read it-is suggesting that the legal restraints on the trade union movement in the course of disputes be removed altogether. At the moment the restraints are there. They are almost unenforceable because of the use of power by trade unions. Yet the Opposition is suggesting that they be further weakened or removed. This is an area recognised within Australia as being one of severe denial of individual human rights. Certainly we need the freedom to join a trade union but perhaps we also need the freedom not to join a trade union. We need the freedom to go on strike and, perhaps, the freedom to decline to go on strike. We have to look only at the pressures being exerted on teachers within my electorate at this very moment. A majority of teachers do not wish to take industrial action. Their human rights are being denied in trying to force them to go on strike by using all sorts of social and other pressures against them. I am not prepared to be lectured by the Opposition on the grave failure of Australia to meet its obligations under the United Nations Convention on Human Rights while the Opposition not only condones but also actively defends practices which are occurring within the industrial arena.

Finally, I believe that this Bill is a cautious but proper advance in the area of human rights in Australia. It builds on a long tradition of human rights guaranteed already under a substantial system of equality under the law. I think it will raise interesting new issues. The appointment of the commissioners will be important. As an example I refer to the Australian Law Reform Commission and the interesting questions raised by His Honour Mr Justice Kirby and his colleagues. We will see similar interesting issues raised by the Human Rights Commission. If this Parliament is asked by the Commission to examine areas where further legislation is needed, I am sure it will be happy to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —The arguments advanced by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) illustrate the fundamental differences between Government and Opposition members in respect of this legislation. One can judge human rights only by the exercise of legislation relating to human rights in Australia. One can determine the level of racial discrimination and the way in which it operates in our community only by looking at a number of situations which have been developed over a period, largely by the Commissioner for Community Relations. For the last five years this Parliament has had annual reports submitted to it by the Commissioner for Community Relations in which he has pointed out and highlighted not merely denials of human rights but also conscious acts of racial discrimination as they occur within our community. Although the honourable member for Mackellar may wax large and say that by and large Australia is better than most other countries in regard to human rights, and I suppose that if we were to compare Australia with El Salvador that is probably a valid statement-perhaps one should look at the evidence put forward in this House.

SPEECH.PARA: This House has spent hours with Government members opposite giving notices of motions. We have spent hours debating human rights in the Soviet Union. But I cannot recall a single occasion on which the Government, a Government member or a Minister of the Government has initiated a debate in the Australian Parliament based upon the reports of its Commissioner for Community Relations. These reports are substantive documents. They run into many pages. The most alarming aspect of the reports-and their substance has never been attacked-is that not only is there racial discrimination in Australia but also one of the vehicles for the continuing perpetration of the racism is the administration of State governments. The Commissioner for Community Relations has, with regret and concern but essentially in discharge of his obligations, cited example after example where racial discrimination has not taken place by accident, it has not taken place as a result of a conservative or boorish attitude in some outback community, but has been the positive result of the ongoing administration and the philosophy of the governments of Queensland and Western Australia.

Has that been a matter of concern to this Government? No, says the honourable member for Mackellar. Let me use his own terms. To an Aboriginal in Queensland or in Western Australia it does not much matter whether one is on the receiving end of Sir Charles Court or Mr Bjelke-Petersen. It does not matter much whether one is a member of the Yungngora community or the Aurukun or Mornington Island community. Cases of racial discrimination have been illustrated and documented time after time. They have been brought to the attention of this House. They have been brought to the attention of the honourable member for Mackellar. But what is his advice to the Australian people? He says: 'With someone like Mr Bjelke-Petersen or Sir Charles Court, it is not a question of the Commonwealth's exercising its constitutional rights. It is not a question of our discharging the mandate which was given to us by the people of Australia in a referendum. It is not even a matter of our honouring the obligations which we undertook as part of the international conventions, which we freely signed'. Oh no. When we are dealing with the political backwoodsmen who represent some of the effective money power that keeps the honourable gentleman opposite in office, to use the terms of the honourable member, what we have to do is to 'engage in public discussion and debate'. We have to coalesce the States into agreeing with our propositions. If the honourable member had read the continuing reports of the Commissioner for Community Relations to the Parliament that gave him the obligation to report instances of discrimination, the honourable member would not simply regard himself as being involved in some kind of awful jest.

Pages 23 to 31 of the 1980 report of the Commissioner for Community Relations deals in detail with racial discrimination in Queensland. It follows the 1979 report in which the Commissioner referred to documents and official policy statements of the Government of Queensland. The infringement of human rights and exercises in racial discrimination do not always involve breaches of State law. What they often involve are continuing acts of administration, one heaped upon another, which in terms of the rights of the individual citizen at the receiving end of that exercise involve a very considerable abrogation of human rights and freedom. I have no doubt that if the honourable member for Mackellar were driving his car along one of the roads in the more remote areas of Queensland and were stopped by a member of the Queensland police force, he would be treated quite differently from the way in which an Aboriginal driver would be treated. That is not something that I am throwing in a glad-handing exercise. It is demonstrated time and again in the reports which have come before this Parliament, reports which have been ignored by this Government and honourable members opposite.

What this legislation is designed to do is to go through the exercise of saying to the people of Australia that of course Malcolm Fraser cares about human rights and one can trust Bjelke-Petersen on issues such as the right to march and Aboriginal land rights. We all know that deep in his heart he has really only been misunderstood on these issues, and we should ignore the track record! The problem with this legislation is that whilst it says yes, we will be very serious in our implementation of human rights documents and we will be very concerned to see that our international obligations are honoured, we will be relying upon the very governments, the very Ministers and the very administrations that have been named time after time, day after day, page after page as being in continual infringement of these rights. Now they will be partners.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had better have a chat with Casey.

—They will be partners with the honourable gentleman opposite in enforcing international conventions. I do not believe it. The people of Australia certainly do not believe it. I do not think that in his heart the honourable member for Mackellar believes it. He does not believe there has been a change in the attitude of the Queensland Government concerning the condemning of Commonwealth policy which increasingly allows for Aboriginal land rights, customary law and tribal language to be developed as goals in themselves. Federally he has supported the concepts but they are condemned in the reports of the Government of Queensland. The honourable member surely does not believe that there has been a change of heart.
—Why don't you go and get your act together in Queensland if you want to do something about it?

—I prefer the integrity of the actions of the Labor Party in Queensland to the wretched performance by one of the most corrupt governments that has ever besmirched the whole concept of the Westminster system in Australia. I suggest that the honourable gentleman ought to make his contribution to the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation. He is not prepared to stand up to the Queensland Premier on issues such as Aboriginal freedom or any of these basic issues, and that is what this legislation is all about.
—This Government has a better record than the Whitlam Government ever had.

—This Government has a reputation. When the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner) was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the choice had to be made between the rights of the minority groups in this community-and I refer especially to the Aboriginal minority groups-there was not a single occasion when the Minister at the table or his colleagues were prepared to take on the Bjelke-Petersen Government or the Court Government, and he knows it. The Government is asking this Parliament to make these State governments equal partners in enforcing international conventions on human rights. This legislation-whatever good might be extracted from it-essentially is a smokescreen designed to dismember the existing Racial Discrimination Act; it is designed to force the present Commissioner for Community Relations out of office; and it is designed to dismember the whole structure of administration which has been created over a period to enable the people of Australia to have reported to them on a continuing basis infringements of human rights and exercies of racial discrimination which have taken place in our community.

SPEECH.PARA: I could say much more on this matter but the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) has a contribution to make and I yield to him. I fully support the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen).

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen). I wish to say a few words also regarding the inclusion of three declarations in the schedules to the Human Rights Commission Bill. Australia does not have a constitutional Bill of Rights and, until recently, had no guarantee of protection of individual freedoms. This was very eloquently spelt out by the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) who preceded me in the debate. Recently, legislation has been passed in the human rights area at both Commonwealth and State levels but that legislation basically concentrates on prohibiting certain actions on specified grounds such as racial discrimination under the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. Under section 51 of the Constitution the Commonwealth can make laws in respect of external affairs for the peace, order and good government of Australia. This power extends to the implementation of an international treaty which imposes obligations on Australia. The general rule is subject to some restrictions so that the treaty is not used just to attract domestic jurisdiction.

SPEECH.PARA: The Human Rights Bill introduced in 1973 by the then Attorney-General, Senator Murphy, relied on those external affairs powers as a means of enacting legislation covering civil rights in Australia. The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights was adopted by the United Nations General Assembly in 1966 and entered into force in 1976. Australia signed the Covenant in December 1972. The Human Rights Bill 1973 sought to give parliamentary approval to its ratification by Australia. It is interesting to go through that Covenant and to repeat the rights contained therein. The Covenant covers such rights as the right to life, freedom of speech, freedom of assembly and association, freedom of religion and conscience, freedom of movement, the right to vote and to hold public office, the right to privacy, freedom from arbitrary arrest, the right to a fair trial and the right not to be subjected to cruel, inhuman or degrading punishment.

The Human Rights Commission Bill 1981 adopts an approach completely different from that of the 1973 Bill. It does not confer human rights on anybody, it does not override inconsistent State laws, and it does not allow for court proceedings if human rights are infringed. It is based on the Covenant which is set out in Schedule 1 to the Bill and also on the three international declarations which are included in the schedules to the Bill and which concern the rights of the child, the rights of the mentally retarded and the rights of disabled persons. There is provision also for other covenants or declarations to be added.

The definition of 'human rights' in the Bill is the rights set out in these declarations. However, only human rights under Commonwealth jurisdiction-that is, under Commonwealth law or practices or in territories other than the Northern Territory-are covered. The functions of the Commission are basically to examine Commonwealth laws and proposed laws to see whether they are in conformity with the Covenant. The Commission can examine also the three declarations-that is, the declaration concerning the rights of the child, the mentally retarded and the disabled-and any new covenants or declarations that are declared. It will report on laws that should be made about human rights and on action necessary to comply with the covenant and other instruments. It will inquire into any act or practice that may be inconsistent with human rights. The last function of the Commission involves the examination of acts or practices by the Commonwealth or its authorities based on the Commonwealth law within a territory or partly within a territory.

The Commission's powers, when inquiring into an act or practice, are sufficient to enable it to call for information or papers and to call witnesses. Failure to assist the Commission when directed is a criminal offence even though some evidence may be withheld on a certificate from the Attorney-General. A person about whom a complaint is made must be given an opportunity to make a submission.

There are some glaring weaknesses in the powers of the Commission. It does not have the power to make orders, not is there an entitlement to go to court if conciliation fails. The Commission is to report to the Minister where it finds that there has been a breach of human rights following an inquiry and where it has not succeeded in conciliating the matter. What can we expect from this Government when that happens? It does not appear that these reports have to be tabled in the Parliament. However, the Commission must make an annual report on its operations which is to be tabled in the Parliament. If a State or the Northern Territory makes an arrangement with the Government the Commission will be able to perform functions on behalf of a State or the Northern Territory, or jointly with the State or Northern Territory authorities. From past performances this would not lead to people having a great deal of confidence in the Commission. Apart from that, the conduct of the States and the Northern Territory will not be at all affected by this Bill.

In August 1980 the Government lodged an instrument of ratification of the Covenant with the United Nations. That Covenant has now come into force in Australia but it was subject to reservations, by far the most important of which was in relation to Article 2 and Article 50 which state that as Australia is a federation it will be for the Commonwealth to implement those matters in relation to which it has power. It will be for the States to implement those matters in relation to which they have power and, where both have the power, the implementation is to be by the constitutionally appropriate authority. The international legality and domestic effect of this reservation is not clear.

Under the Vienna Convention on Treaties reservations are allowed but they must not expressly prohibit or be incompatible with the object and purpose of the treaty. Article 50 of the Covenant is an attempt to prevent federal states from opting out of their responsibilities. It can be argued that the reservations to Article 2 and Article 50 may be regarded as being prohibited by Article 50. If not, it can be argued that a reservation which leaves responsibility for implementing the great majority of rights to State governments is contrary to the object and purpose of the treaty and, as such, is invalid. If provisions of the Covenant are not implemented it will be the responsibility of this Parliament and not of the States. It has become quite clear that reservations in relation to Article 2 and Article 50 by this Government were for the purpose of satisfying the States and, therefore, the Commonwealth could not in the future use the external affairs power to pass legislation overriding State laws. The argument would be that no obligations had arisen under the Covenant for the Commonwealth to legislate except on matters where it had exclusive powers. Accordingly, no occasion has arisen for the use of the external affairs power. Against this it could be argued that if the reservation is illegal internationally it has no effect and cannot be seen as limiting the obligations placed on the Commonwealth to have the convention implemented for Australia.

I wish to comment briefly on the provisions of the Bill and to make a specific reference to the unborn child by means of the inclusion of the United Nations Declaration of the Rights of the Child. That declaration contains a preamble which reads in part:
Whereas the child, by reason of his physical and mental immaturity needs special safeguards and care, including appropriate legal protection, before as well as after birth.

Some honourable members could say that as the honourable member for McMillan, I have more than a casual interest in matters relating to this issue. In 1980, in this House, Mr Martyr moved an amendment which was further amended by my predecessor. That amendment was passed by the House of Representatives but was never accepted by the Senate. I am pleased to support the inclusion of the reference to the unborn child. I made it quite plain last year before the election that I intended to support legislation which recognised the rights of the child before birth. I believe in 1981 we are far past unscientific ideas as to when life begins. Today it is an undisputed scientific fact that human life begins at fertilisation.

Recently I had the privilege of hearing Dr Bernard Natheson speaking at Melbourne University. Dr Natheson, who was in the forefront of the campaign in the United States to get early available abortions in that country, spoke eloquently about certain new data and information which he now specialises in. This new data has convinced Dr Natheson that the life and rights of the child before birth ought to be protected by law. In fact, he goes so far as to say that in the United States it should be done by constitutional amendment.

Those in Australia who are concerned with human rights should be pleased that for the first time in Federal legislation the child before birth is getting explicit recognition. It should be seen as a first step, a step forward in overcoming the discrimination practised against the unborn. I wish to quote from an article which I read in the Age dated 24 March. The article stated:
A girl born as doctors were trying to perform an abortion on a woman about eight months' pregnant was ''stabilised and . . . doing fine'', hospital officials in Phoenix, Arizona, said yesterday.
The woman told doctors she was 19 weeks pregnant. The only examination she received before the operation on Friday failed to reveal how advanced the pregnancy was.

Those operations are taking place in the United States. With the repeal of the laws which have taken place there it is no wonder there is some need to protect the rights of the unborn. That is the way I see the recognition of the unborn. I would hope that the Commission will take a lead in educating the Australian community in the true status and rights of the unborn child. The Commission is to promote an awareness of human rights and to promote an understanding and an acceptance of those rights. If the Commission exercises its role in relation to the child before birth, it is hoped that we will see a decline in the present figure for abortions, which almost everybody agrees is quite unacceptably high. I look to other measures in the future designed to reduce the loss of human life resulting from abortions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on one or two aspects of the Human Rights Commission Bill. I support the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen). When the Government considered this Bill it was presented with an opportunity to make full use of its external affairs power as defined in section 51, placitum (xix) of the Constitution to remedy abuses of human rights in this nation. This is evident from the fact that it is essentially international convenants which the Bill utilises to provide the criteria against which human rights violations shall be judged. In the Bill the Government has chosen not to do this. It is largely on its failure to make the operations of the Human Rights Commission applicable to areas of State jurisdiction and even the Northern Territory and to provide it with teeth to enforce its findings that we object to it in its current form.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is a monument to the poverty of the Liberal Party's philosophy, about which we are supposed to hear a great deal in this Parliament. There is the assertion that this Government is committed to and values human freedom above all other considerations but we cannot permit a Bill to apply to State legislation and actions because this would upset the separation of powers between the States and the centre, a separation based on political expendiency at the time of its enactment and justified in the long term in terms of administrative and political convenience. Administrative arrangements have been elevated to the plain of high principle by this Government. As this Bill stands, they override considerations of human freedom. That is done both explicitly and tacitly throughout the Bill. Occasionally an argument is put forward by honourable members opposite that this separation of powers guarantees a decentralisation of power which in itself promotes freedom. There is nothing essentially wrong with this argument in principle. Where it falls flat in this instance is in its application to this Bill and in the operations of State governments.

It might be argued legitimately that the powers of the Schools Commission, for example, ought not be extended because this would encroach on the freedom of local populations to have a say in the educational process. It might be argued that total Commonwealth authority over determining the pace and character of mineral developments, particularly the developments of mining communities, undermines to a degree democratic practice and that State rights here are a value. It cannot be argued that in any shape or form the defence of individual liberties and rights at the expense of State authority offends any democratising effects of our current Federal arrangements. This is precisely because an appropiately empowered Human Rights Commission would pick up State legislation and action at those points where decentralised power does not have a democratising effect. In other words, an education policy which is good for Western Australia may not be good for Queensland. However, if human rights mean anything at all, in no circumstances can an internationally agreed definition of human liberty be valid for Canberra and a test of Commonwealth legislation but not for Western Australia and legislation in the various States.

The offences committed by conservative governments in my home State against the civil and political liberties entailed in international convenants which provide the frame of reference for this albeit toothless Commission have been gross. They have called into question the rights of citizens to assemble and speak. They have called into question the rights of individuals to vote. They have made a mockery of the extension to the original inhabitants of this land of some form of recognition of their original proprietary rights. These actions are possible largely because the Electoral Act of the State of Western Australia operates in systematic violation of the spirit and letter of Article 25 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which is the basis of the operations of this Commission. In part that guarantee states:
To vote and to be elected at genuine periodic elections which shall be universal and equal suffrage and shall be held by secret ballot, guaranteeing the free expression of the will of electors.

The term 'equal suffrage' implies an equal value in every individual's vote. Only by such a process can the free expression of the will of the electors be guaranteed. The United States Bill of Rights, which contains similar provisions, has been used to end malapportionment. A proper human rights Bill here might well have done the same and may have stopped the ludicrous situation that exists in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Queensland.

—And Queensland, but it is much worse in Western Australia. This is not generally realised. Western Australia is divided into three zones-metropolitan and country, where quotas for seats are set, and a northern zone, where the seat boundaries are covered by separate statutes. In the metropolitan area the quota for electors per seat for the Legislative Assembly is 17,264. In the country zone the quota is 9,139. The metropolitan zone has a total of 466,150 electors for 27 representatives. The country and statute zones have a total of 246,060 electors for 28 representatives. The largest Assembly seat is Whitford with 30,790 electors on the roll. All these figures are for January this year. The smallest seat is Murchison-Eyre, a statute seat, with 1,925 electors on the roll. The ratio is 16 to one. The situation in the Upper House, the Legislative Council, is even worse. A quarter of a million country voters have 20 members whilst half a million city voters have 12 members. The largest Council province is North Metropolitan with 97,556 electors. The smallest is Lower North with 5,764. That is a margin of 17 to one. It may well be that in political terms the current governing authorities in Queensland are not the greatest burglars; they are outdone by those who operate our system in Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Human Rights Commission Bill had contained the capacity to intervene and to examine where State legislation offended against the rights of individual Australians, there would have been some possibility of bringing these matters to the attention of the general Australian community and having them redressed. The Bill denies us that opportunity. Had the Bill been in the same form as it was originally proposed by the Labor Government at least those of us who desire to see democratic practice extended to the decentralised aspects of the Australian governing process would have found the Human Rights Commission of ready assistance in that regard.

The Bill, in its revised form, now includes within the Commission's terms of reference an area of human rights which are not strictly civil and political. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has done this in order to incorporate within the Bill, without directly stating it, an interpretation of the right to life which extends prior to birth. This has been, I believe-I agree here with the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham)-a positive step. It also needs to be recognised that this extends the nature of the rights considered in this legislation in directions not normally contemplated by honourable members opposite. In dealing with the rights of children, handicapped and disabled people we are entering the realm of social and economic policy. For example, principle 4 of the Declaration of the Rights of the Child states:

The child shall enjoy the benefits of social security. He shall be entitled to grow and develop in health; to this end, special care and protection shall be provided both to him and to his mother, including adequate pre-natal and post-natal care. The child shall have the right to adequate nutrition, housing, recreation and medical services.

Honourable members have never accepted that these areas of social welfare involve individual's rights. The theory of the social policy of honourable members opposite has always been founded on the notion of the deserving poor. Those termed undeserving have been the object on occasions of attack and vilification. This has been the case, of course, as we are all aware in this House, with the young unemployed. The deserving and the undeserving alike are assigned a status which permits a certain level of government parsimoniousness. That ought not to be permitted if we regard these matters-the Government evidently does, as shown by its approach to this legislation-as matters of fundamental right.

I for one intend to encourage the many electors in my constituency who do not have adequate access to post-natal and pre-natal care for their children with the decline of our hospital system; who do not have adequate housing and recreation; who do not, if disabled, have adequate opportunities to work; who do not have access to free education; and who have had in real terms family support cut back to them to appear before this Commission and demand their rights in the terms that the Government has permitted them to proceed to do. If mothers and fathers receive adequate support in childbirth and rearing-by 'adequate' I mean support which will permit them their right to pursue a chosen profession as well as the assumption of responsibility for the child rearing-this legislation might well have an impact on abortion statistics in ways not wholly to be anticipated by the way in which the debate on the subject has proceeded to this point. In other words, it will deal not only with the question of the legal rights of the unborn child but also with the level of assistance to the mothers and the parents at all stages not only at the child's birth but also in the child's life. That would create a situation where abortion, for many people who are using the option of abortion at the moment, would not seem necessary.

I do not really think, however, the Government will follow up this legislation with the very necessary social legislation to ensure that these rights as they are now defined are in fact adequately protected. Were the Government to do so, I think we would find, certainly in my electorate, an extremely grateful population. The fact that the Government has not done so imposes upon me an obligation to assist my constituents in whatever way I can, under whatever terms, conditions and opportunities that this Commission provides, to get the limited succour that is possible. I hope the amendment moved by the Opposition is carried. It would give the social as well as the civil and political, libertarian aspects of this legislation a chance to be enforced not only at the Federal but also at the State level. I am pleased to support the very sensible amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable members for the contribution that they have made to the debate on the Human Rights Commission Bill. I regret that the Opposition should feel disposed to move the amendment which would have the effect of withdrawing the Bill and therefore defeating its passage. I would have thought, with the time that this Parliament has spent in the endeavours that it has undertaken to put on the statute book a Bill to establish a Human Rights Commission, the Opposition would have been as anxious as the Government to see that this Commission comes into being. The Government cannot accept the amendment for that fundamental reason. We believe the establishment of this Commission and the bringing into operation of the covenants that it endorses are so important that we ought not to delay any longer the passage of this Bill. Therefore, the Government will be voting against the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Both sides of this House have applauded at least two matters. The first is the declarations with regard to children that were referred to in my second reading speech-the Declaration of the Rights of the Child, 1959, the Declaration on the Rights of the Mentally Retarded, 1971, and the Declaration on the Rights of the Disabled, 1975. The Declaration of the Rights of the Child, as honourable members on both sides of the House have recognised, states:
. . . the child, by reason of his physical and mental immaturity, needs special safeguards and care, including appropriate legal protection, before as well as after birth . . .

The second matter which has received some but not a great deal of attention is the deletion from sub-clause (4) of clause 10 of the original Bill of paragraph (f) which would have given to the Commission a discretion to decide not to hold an inquiry with regard to a complaint which was thought not of sufficient concern to the complainant. That discretion has been removed. Therefore, it should strengthen the power and authority of the Commission.

This debate like so many debates with regard to rights of any kind has evoked a variety of opinion as to what are rights and in particular what rights ought to be protected one way or another within the political framework of the country. Of course, if one goes back through history the debate on the rights of the individual has been one of constant philosophical and social argument. The debate in this House tonight is no exception. History has not changed nor have the attitudes of people. It is a fact that some of us approach the meaning of rights in a different way to others. I listened with interest to the contribution of the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly). Perhaps over the course of history this debate about what is meant by rights is rather epitomised by the way in which St Paul viewed the rights of women and the way in which the Women's Electoral Lobby of today views the rights of women.

Some rights, some of us would say, are fundamental. If we wish to look at the matter in a Christian sense, the Ten Commandments are as fundamental as anything which has ever been expressed by humans in the course of history. In the course of legal development through parts of the United Kingdom-the history of that country has been brought down to us through the common law-some rights are derived from those fundamental Christian rights, some are the result of the development of human attitudes and are reflected in the statutes of the United Kingdom and hence in this country. It may well be said that the rights expressed through statute law are more changeable, more dynamic in a sense, than those that are expressed through the common law. That is understandable because people of different views come and go from government. Hence they have the power which government gives to them through the parliamentary system.

Perhaps the difference of view as to what are rights and whether they ought to be enforced in one way or another meets its modern classic expression in the dichotomy of views with regard to abortion. We have heard something about that tonight. There are those who say that a women has a right to destroy life. There are others, such as myself and the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham), who say that the right of a person created is the right to survive. That is a modern, classic expression of difference of views on what are meant by rights.

So when we listen to a debate such as we have heard tonight we ought to consider the different expression of views in that way. Therefore, it is fair to say that neither side of this House should gather around itself the cloak of righteousness in its belief as to what is best for individuals in this country. On this side we happen to have a particular view based on a philosophy of liberalism, which in its most simple terms is an expression of the liberty of the individual. That does differ from the socialist attitude of members of the Opposition and we will, as long as we are in this Parliament, debate with vigour that difference in philosophy and uphold the correctness of our view.

Another expression of difference of view is in the way in which we believe that the Constitution of Australia should be utilised for the benefit of the citizens of Australia. Whether the Opposition likes it or not, Australia has a Federal political structure. Again, whether the Opposition likes it or not, our Constitution is based on the fundamental premise of the distribution of power, both legal and political. We recognise that. We believe that it is a virtue in political terms, historically in its recognition of human nature and in the fact that the people of Australia live in geographically different parts; that there is value in allowing people in those different parts of Australia to express their aspirations through their own political structure. Of course, that is reflected in the political structure of the States and the Territories.

Quite clearly, if the external affairs power of the Constitution, which has been referred to by the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) with such admiration, were allowed its full blossoming under a socialist government such as we experienced during the Whitlam years, the fundamental distribution of powers, as expressed in the Constitution, would be destroyed by the socialist objective of the Labor Party-to centralise political and economic power in Canberra. We on this side have no hesitation in saying that we believe that such a concentration of power would be bad. There is no proper distinction, such as the honourable member for Swan sought to draw, between the use of the external affairs power in the human rights field and its use in any other field. So the Government has no hesitation in affirming its policy, often stated publicly, that it will not use the external affairs power to subvert that fundamental distribution of political power that is provided for by the Constitution. Some honourable members opposite have expressed regret that the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights is not to fall within the jurisdiction of this Commission but as the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) pointed out in the Senate, the legislation contains powers by which the charter of the Commission can be extended to include covenants of that kind.

In regard to the complaint-perhaps not un- naturally made-by the female members of this House that the Commission's jurisdiction will not extend to the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, I would point out that Australia is as yet only a signatory to that Convention. It was not until July 1980, I believe, that the Convention was framed and Australia became a signatory. As is natural in the course of international events, all countries must consider whether and when they will ratify that convention. Ratification is a separate and distinctive international act which flows from merely being a signatory. So the Commonwealth is conducting discussions with the States in accordance with its federalist policy before determining whether Australia will ratify that convention. When it makes such a decision it will be appropriate to consider whether the Commission will have jurisdiction in regard to that Convention.

It is always very difficult for a male member of the House to answer comment such as we heard from the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) who declared that much discrimination is perpetrated against women in our community. The honourable member mentioned discrimination with respect to employment. I was very glad to support not only the efforts of my Department, but also those of other departments of the Commonwealth, including the Public Service Board, and to identify myself with the actions of the National Labour Consultative Council, which includes representatives of both employers and unions, in embarking upon a vigorous program to promote equal opportunity for the employment of women. That program will be implemented as fully as it can be. Likewise, within the Public Service Board the equal opportunity unit is a vigorous, constructive unit aimed at opening up ever widening opportunities for women to be employed. Although certain numbers were quoted by the honourable member with respect to the proportion of women who were in the First and Second divisions of the Public Service, I think it is fair to consider history. We can understand why, because of social attitudes, those numbers are so small today, but it is likewise equally fair to judge that, because of the continuing change in those attitudes, and programs such as the equal opportunity program for the employment of women, we will see an increasing number of women in the higher levels of the Commonwealth Public Service and also, I would hope, in the public services of the various States and Territories of the Commonwealth.

Some mention was made of the reservations expressed by Australia in regard to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. I firmly believe, as does the Attorney-General, that the reservations and declarations that have been expressed are completely in accord with the Vienna Convention. We simply do not accept that, in the form in which they are drafted, the Federal-State paragraphs are in breach of that Convention or contrary to the objects or purposes of the Covenant. Indeed, they are consistent with the Federal political structure of Australia and with the authority given by the Covenant to make reservations and declarations.

For those reasons, and others which have been expressed in the second reading speeches of myself and the Attorney-General in the Senate, the Government cannot accept the proposed amendment and wishes to see this Bill passed and brought into law quickly and effectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take this opportunity to dispose of a further episode in the pattern of deception in which the Government has engaged in this House in recent times. It relates to certain factual matters concerning what has happened in recent years regarding wage movements and the responsibility for those wage movements. In the House earlier today the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), in answering a question by me, was pleased to mislead the House. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable gentleman knows quite well that the policies that he devised when he was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions that led to wage increases of nearly 40 per cent in one year, in 1975 . . .

He later went on to say that he was talking about the period of a year up to March 1975. I want to take the time of the House to put the record straight. I refer to what happened to wage movements in the whole of the year 1975. The Prime Minister purported to talk about wage movements but attempted to justify his argument by producing figures in regard to minimum weekly rates. They have nothing to do with wage movements. He took the concocted period March 1974 to March 1975 and showed that the weighted average minimum weekly wage rates moved by 37.6 per cent. On that basis he attempted to justify this exaggerated movement in wages of 40 per cent. The average figure for the whole of the year was 23.6 per cent. The figure for the period December to December was 13.5 per cent.

Is the logic of the Prime Minister's argument that, because wages moved by 37.6 per cent from March to March and by 13.5 per cent from December to December, my capacity to influence the movement in wage rates diminished by approximately two-thirds between March and December? That must be his logic because if I was responsible for what happened to wage movements apparently my power peaked in the March to March period but diminished by two-thirds in the period December to December. The absurdity of the proposition only has to be stated for even the braying members opposite to understand the absolute lack of logic in what the Prime Minister had to say. The period in question is not this concocted period of March 1974 to March 1975, for which the Prime Minister latched upon the level of 37.6 per cent.

The Prime Minister purported to talk about the movement in wages. As all economists know-I know that includes no honourable member opposite-a consideration of the movement in wages involves looking at average earnings. That is what we talk about when we refer to movements in wages, which is what the Prime Minister said he was talking about-not wage rates; he said wages. Let us look at the facts so that honourable members can consider them instead of the deliberate misrepresentations which continuously emanate from the Prime Minister and his lackey, the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner), whom he sends in here.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! I ask the honourable member for Wills to withdraw.

—I withdraw; of course he is not a lackey. I refer to the movements in wages-that is what the Prime Minister purported to talk about, not wage rates-in 1975. This i what happened in the quarterly figures for 1975. The figure for March to March is 26.2; for June to June, 22 per cent; for September to September, 13.4 per cent; and for December to December, 12.8 per cent. The 1975 figure for wage movements was 18.7 per cent, not the 40 per cent with which the Prime Minister and his representative, the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, deliberately misled this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I read an article today in the Melbourne Herald about the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) which said that he was a very calm politician, and that he never got riled or ruffled. I think the writer should rethink the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: About two weeks ago I had probably the misfortune to appear as a witness for a former member of this House, a very distinguished member, well known to the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman). He gave evidence at an appeal hearing. The story that he unfolded was very sad and it was one that made me realise that as young people many of us are completely unaware of some of the problems faced by those people who participated in combat in the theatre of war. The younger generation seems to have forgotten some of the things they endured.

Today I received a letter from Mr Nelson, the honorary secretary of the Newcastle Wartime Seamen's Association. I read the letter very carefully and I think he has a very good point. In essence the letter states:

We solicit your support in an attempt to have proper recognition of the part played by the merchant seamen during World War II. The gun crews of merchant ships were responsible for the destruction of many hundreds of enemy aeroplanes, a number of submarines and at least on five occasions merchant ships emulated the heroic actions of the Jervis Bay in taking on many warships of far superior gun power.
At the bottom of the letter, in his own handwriting, Mr Nelson said:
I have been told you have a deep and sincere interest in this particular issue. Your support would be most welcome.

The Association has my support because I believe that it has a very good case. Some people who left Australia but did not enter the war zone are nevertheless eligible for a Service pension. However some of these poor fellows in the merchant marine went through hell and high water during the war and I am afraid that they entered that service at a very young age. Many are now approaching the age of 60 or they are over 60. They must have suffered during the war. I believe that it is up to every young politician to realise that they were dreadful years. We are apt to forget the suffering of these people, as we forget many other things that occurred during that period. I believe that that Association has a good case and I believe--

TALK.START.PARA: —They deserve a fair go.

—Of course. The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) said that the members of the Association deserve a fair go. I am glad that he is helping me tonight with a few words. I seem to be stuck. After listening to the honourable member for Wills all day I am stuck for a few words. As I said, the Association has a very good case and I believe that we should all start to fight for it because it deserves a fair go.

SPEECH.PARA: Ten AMSWU members and 18 FIA members employed on No. 2 bloom mill maintenance stopped work at 9.15 a.m. over the removal of a danger tag. Work was resumed at 7.30 a.m. on 24 February . . . Just listen to the contents of the trivial issue on which the union leaders called them out. On 24 February this year 135 FIA members and 10 AMSWU members employed on No. 2 bloom mill maintenance and production stopped work at 8 a.m. in protest at the use of apprentices during a previous stoppage. Work was resumed at 8 a.m. on 25 February.

I have here a letter from one of the men involved in that matter who came to see me. He was most indignant about the statement made by the honourable member for Petrie, which was not factual. The position is that on 23 February this year, the tradesman who came to see me, and his assistant, were working on a machine in the bloom mill, which is the largest rolling mill in the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd steel-making process. They were working with a C-spanner to take off a nut. They were using a 4-foot length of 2-inch piping to give them additional leverage. They just loosened the nut, took it off, put the spanner down and the machine started to operate. This is what brought about the stoppage about which the honourable member for Petrie made remarks to which the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) took exception.

The position is that that machine had 10 danger tags on it which said that under no circumstances must it be started. Each danger tag has the name of the operator, the name of the department and the date on it. Yet the supervisor instructed an inexperienced young fitter to start the machine, notwithstanding the fact that there were 10 danger tags on it. The company's policy is that under no circumstances must the machine be started when it has a danger tag on it. Yet on that day there were at least 10 tags on that switch. So on this supervisor's instruction the machine was started. That is why the men went on strike. I can tell honourable members that any time that sort of thing happens in BHP or in any heavy industrial works, then we will be looking at a stoppage, a most justifiable stoppage by the men. If that fitter and his mate, hanging on that 4-foot length of 2-inch pipe had been there another minute, God knows where they would have finished up. We would probably have had to attend their funeral. But according to the honourable member for Petrie that is a trivial dispute. The men had a dispute. They endeavoured to get the foreman or the supervisor suspended, and they could not. But two days later they did succeed in getting the supervisor suspended because he had not put a danger tag on a switch that he had men working on.

The honourable member for Petrie says that the next day the men went on strike because apprentices did tradesmen's work. That is not correct. They went on strike on the second occasion because staff labour was used to do work normally performed by men who were on strike. It was not the apprentices who brought about the dispute. There were three days of disputes. The first day a fitter and turner and his assistant were fortunate they did not get killed because the machine was started up.
